人;person;The character for _enter_ (Frame 842) showed someone walking inwards (in terms of the direction of writing), the one for **person** , shown here, represents someone walking outwards.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 27-11-2008(156): Behold Mister T (of "A-Team" fame)! I chose Mr.T because he's sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since he's both the big, tough guy and the “moralistic” **person** , telling kids not “to do drugs or alcohol”. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line “I pity da foo!” * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a “T”.;2) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 1-10-2006(44): [I appreciate some people's occasional habit of using _P_ for **person** in shared stories. That makes it easier to substitute _Mr. T_ , _Captain Picard_ , or whomever else a student is using as **person.** ].
一;one;In Chinese characters, the number **one** is laid on its side, unlike the Roman numeral I which stands upright. As you would expect, it is written from left to right.;1) [[Piitaa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Piitaa)] 29-6-2006(263): **One** down, 2041 to go. ,).;2) [[findus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/findus)] 11-5-2008(98): To learn this **one** kanji, I [recommend](../v4/2000.html) (#2000 薦) this story : _Bambi_ is in a _cave_ , eating a side-dish of _salad_ when trying to learn the kanjis. As he succeed to learn the kanji for "one", you get jealous and decide to shoot him with a _slingshot_. At this moment you hear the police coming, so you hurriedly burn all the proofs into a _fire_ (so you remove the key-words _Bambi_ , _slingshot_ and _fire_ from _recommend_ ). So that when the police arrives, the only remaining clue is a single horizontal bar.
見;see;The elements that compose the character for **see** are the _eye_ firmly fixed to a pair of _human legs_. Surely, somewhere in your experience, there is a vivid image just waiting to be dragged up to help you remember this character....;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 29-6-2007(146): As a primitive, this is Mike Wazowski from Monsters Inc. (the giant _eyeball_ with _legs_ …) Makes for _easy_ stories later on.;2) [[frenchdonuts](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/frenchdonuts)] 24-6-2008(124): Eyes and legs are all you need to **see** the world.
出;exit;The kanji for **exit** pictures a series of mountain peaks coming out of the _earth_. Learn it together with the following frame.;1) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 4-1-2008(141): Suddenly, a _cactus_ comes out of the ground with a sign that reads: **exit**. Now you can leave the desert! (Note: giving this primitive the meaning 'cactus' can be useful later).;2) [[theBryan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/theBryan)] 19-7-2008(63): The **exit** lays between these two mountains.
日;day;This kanji is intended to be a pictograph of the sun. Recalling what we said in the previous frame about round forms, it is easy to detect the circle and the big smile that characterize our simplest drawings of the sun - like those yellow badges with the words, "Have a nice **day**! ";1) [[Alphinux](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Alphinux)] 23-1-2008(120): Open the window, new **day**.;2) [[ibnfe2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ibnfe2)] 30-12-2006(18): Picture two halves of a 24-hr period: **Day** & Night.
来;come;This odd but common kanji is built up of the character for _not yet_ into which a pair of _animal horns_ has been inserted.;1) [[ikmys](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ikmys)] 22-2-2007(346): You _horny_ bastard, don't **come** , at least _not yet_!;2) [[volfy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/volfy)] 12-5-2006(72): When I **come** home, there's nobody and no dinner waiting for me. Sigh… _rice_ for _one_ again.
大;large;Here we have a simple pictograph of a person, taking up the space of an entire character and giving it the sense of **large**. It should not be too hard to locate the two legs and outstretched arms.;1) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 13-9-2007(79): A person stretching their arms and legs to look **large** and scare a bear away.;2) [[Teango](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Teango)] 8-3-2010(23): How **large**? This **large**!
子;child;This kanji is a pictograph of a **child** wrapped up in one of those handy cocoons that Japanese mothers fix to their backs to carry around young **children** who cannot get around by themselves. The first stroke is like a wee head popping out for air, the second shows the body and legs all wrapped up, and the final stroke shows the arms sticking out to cling to the mother's neck.;1) [[lbphenom](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lbphenom)] 12-1-2008(43): A **child** who is _ten_ will still ask for his _ma_ (top looks a bit like katakana ma).;2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 28-1-2008(30): A pictograph of a **child** , with arms outstretched for mother (or perhaps because she is chasing a rat?). Note that this kanji occupies the first space on the Zodiac circle, and is the sign for the rat (such as 2008!).
思;think;Brains . . . heart.;1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 8-7-2006(237): **Think** with your _brain_ NOT your _heart_.;2) [[PacifistGod](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PacifistGod)] 8-4-2007(153): To **think** is to use your brain over your heart.
行;going;By joining the top four strokes, you should get a picture of the front current of a river, the stream trailing behind. Hence the character for **going**.;1) [[jackhuddleston](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jackhuddleston)] 3-5-2008(76): To me, this looks like a bridge **going** over a body of water, being supported by columns underneath it. Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and **going** constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here.;2) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 4-11-2005(53): I use _The Flash_ for for this primitive, a superhero who is always _going_ very fast.
時;time;"What is **time**? " asked St. Augustine in his memoirs. "Ask me not, and I know. Ask me, and I cannot tell you." Here we have the kanji's answer to that perennial riddle. **Time** is a _sun_ rising over a _Buddhist temple_. It sounds almost like a Zen kōan whose repetition might yield some deep secret to the initiated. At any rate, imagining a monk seated in meditation pondering it might help us remember the character.;1) [[zdnks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zdnks)] 31-10-2007(120): When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it's **time** to get up.;2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 27-2-2008(102): In ancient Japan, **TIME** of ''day'' was announced at the ''buddhist temples''. They did this by ringing large iron bells. This is similar to churches who ring their bells to announce the **time** of day.
上;above;The two directions, **above** and below, are usually pointed at with the finger. But the characters do not follow that custom, so we have to choose something else, easily remembered. The primitives show a _magic wand_ standing **_above_** a _floor_  \- "magically," you might say. Anyway, go right on to the next frame, since the two belong together and are best remembered as a unit, just as the words **above** and _below_ suggest each other.;1) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 2-7-2007(58): A _magic wand_ standing on **above** the floor.;2) [[ruschein](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruschein)] 4-1-2009(18): The _divining rod_ is **above** the _floor_.
分;part;Go in . . . dagger.;1) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 4-1-2007(159): When something is _entered_ by a _dagger_ , it ends up being cut in several **parts**.;2) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 21-3-2008(147): (This kanji also has the meanings of "understand" and "minute"). It's important to understand that were you to _enter_ an hour with a _dagger_ and cut it into **parts** , those **parts** would be minutes.
私;private;_Wheat_ . . . _elbow_. Like the characters for I (Frame 17) and _ego_ (Frame 690), this kanji is also representative of the subject, with the special connotation of **privacy**.;1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 1-5-2006(294): Warning sign: "Private wheat, trespassers will be elbowed".;2) [[hilber](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/hilber)] 12-12-2009(114): A joke so bad as "wheatashi wa" deserves an elbow in the **private** parts.
中;in;The elements here are a _walking stick_ and a _mouth_. Remember the trouble your mother had getting medicine **in** your _mouth_? Chances are it crossed her mind more than once to grab something handy, like your grandfather's _walking stick_ , to pry open your jaws while she performed her duty. Keep the image of getting something **in** from the outside, and the otherwise abstract sense of this key word should be a lot easier than trying to spoon castor oil **in** to a baby's mouth.;1) [[Rose_Arteth](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rose_Arteth)] 17-8-2007(143): Pocky goes **in** the mouth.;2) [[samesong](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samesong)] 22-3-2009(116): My GF lets me come **in** her mouth (pictogram).
事;matter;This key word here refers to abstract **matters**. The elements are: _one_ . . . _mouth_ . . . _rake_. Note how the _rake_ handle reaches out the top and bottom of the character.;1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 16-9-2007(216): Just _one_ word about this **matter** from your _mouth_ and you will find this _rake_ across it.;2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 18-11-2007(109): I had to take _one_ day off from work due to 'personal **matter** s' after stepping on a _rake_ and having the handle snap up and smack me across the _mouth_. I certainly wasn't going to tell anyone about it.
何;what;Person . . . can.;1) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 22-1-2008(157): **What** can Mr T do? 'You mean: **what** can't MR T do, you fool'.;2) [[msukovich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/msukovich)] 6-5-2008(44): " **What** country you from?" " **W-what**?" "' **What** ' ain't no country I ever heard of, they speak English in ' **What** '?" " **W-w-what**?" "ENGLISH, MOTHERFUCKER, _CAN_ YOU SPEAK IT?" "Yes!" "Now describe **what** this _person_ Marsellus Wallace looks like!" " **W-w-w-what**?" "Say ' **what** ' again! SAY ' **WHAT** ' AGAIN! I dare you! I double-dare you, motherfucker! Say ' **what** ' one more god-damn time!".
二;two;Like the Roman numeral II, which reduplicates the numeral I, the kanji for **two** is a simple reduplication of the horizontal stroke that means one. The order of writing goes from above to below, with the first stroke slightly shorter.;1) [[kiisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kiisu)] 15-1-2008(54): **Two** lines.;2) [[mazel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mazel)] 10-9-2006(24): Roman numeral II, written on its side.
自;oneself;You can think of this kanji as a stylized pictograph of the nose, that little _drop_ that Mother Nature set between your _eyes_. The Japanese refer to themselves by pointing a finger at their nose - giving us an easy way to remember the kanji for **oneself**.;1) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 2-7-2007(140): To use an eyedropper by **oneself** , aim from _above_ to put a _drop_ into the _eye_.;2) [[pikako](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pikako)] 14-11-2007(89): Faced with his clone, our hero valiantly cut a _mark_ on his forehead right above his _eye_ so that his comrades could tell his true **oneself** from the enemy.
彼;he;_Going_ . . . _pelt_. This kanji refers to the third person singular personal pronoun, generally in its masculine form.;1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 28-5-2007(309): What's the main difference between a **he** and a she? The **he** has a _column_ covered in a _pelt_ … a penis. Badum-ching.;2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 8-1-2008(58): The ultimate **he** -man is the Neanderthal cave man. His club is as big as a pillar ( _column_ ), and **he** wears a ragged _pelt_ as his only clothing. To remember the _column_ , imagine the cave man resting the club vertically like a column when not in use.
方;direction;Spinning a _dagger_ about on its hilt on the top of a _top hat_  \- waiting to see in which **direction** it points when it comes to rest - one leaves to fate where one is going next. Take care in writing this character.;1) [[Deonnn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Deonnn)] 9-12-2007(147): Note: The primitives are _top hat_ and _bound up_. Compare [ten thousand](../v4/64.html) (#64 万). Story: A rich man wearing a _top hat_ and _bound up_ from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for **directions** to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers.;2) [[CSBarnes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CSBarnes)] 15-12-2008(49): I always keep my **directions** _bound_ to the bottom of my _top hat_ so I won't lose them.
生;life;A single _drop_ added to the element for _grow up_ gives us the character for **life**.;1) [[TheSleeve](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/TheSleeve)] 5-11-2007(221): This is the first CELL of a human, the foundation of its entire **LIFE** , a small DROP that will GROW UP to form a complex organism.;2) [[brian44](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brian44)] 19-12-2007(29): Growing Up is just a Drop of our **LIFE**.
間;interval;_Gates_ . . . _sun/day_. This **interval** applies to time and space alike, but the latter is better for creating an image.;1) [[shaydwyrm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shaydwyrm)] 28-6-2007(203): The **interval** between star systems ( _suns_ ) was too large, so the star _gates_ were created to travel between them.;2) [[sgrant](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sgrant)] 16-2-2009(95): We open the _gates_ at regular **intervals** to let a bit of _sun_ in.
手;hand;Any way you count them, there are either too many or too few fingers to see a good pictograph of a **hand** in this character. But that it is, and so you must.;1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 31-1-2007(99): This pictograph actually really works if you look at it as a **hand** with fingers spread and middle finger pointing down. see the very top stroke as the edge of a shirt cuff, and it will all come together.;2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 4-8-2009(86): A **hand** is useful for 千一 (1001) things.
言;say;Of all the things we can do with our _mouths_ , speech is the one that requires the greatest distinctness and clarity. Hence the kanji for **say** has four little sound-waves, indicating the complexity of the achievement.;1) [[jinka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jinka)] 28-4-2006(109): A pictogram of someone **saying** a _four_ letter word from their _mouth_ after the censors have gotten a hold of it.;2) [[sethg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethg)] 4-2-2009(68): This is simple a pictogram of a _mouth_ **SAY** ing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.
女;woman;You have probably seen somewhere the form of a squatting **woman** drawn behind this character, with two legs at the bottom, two arms (the horizontal line) and the head poking out the top. A little farfetched, until you draw the character and feel the grace and flow of the three simple strokes. Remembering the kanji is easy, being able to write it beautifully is another thing.;1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 14-1-2007(216): To remember the order of strokes, remember a female ninja is called a "kunoichi". That is, く(hiragana) ノ(katakana) 一 (kanji, ichi=one).;2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 24-7-2007(29): My mother taught me that a **woman** should always sit with her legs crossed (but the arms can be stretched out).
本;book;Recalling that **books** are made of paper, and paper made of _trees_ , one might think of a **book** as a slice of a _tree_. Can you seethe  "cross-cut" in the trunk of the _tree_? Picture it as a chainsaw cutting you out a few **books** with which to start your own private library.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 31-7-2007(73): The origin of a **book** is paper made out of TREEs. ONE tree can make many **book** s.;2) [[ggwar](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ggwar)] 7-8-2009(25): A **book** is _one_ slice of a _tree_.
気;spirit;The **spirit** in this character refers to the changeable moods and airs of one's personality as well as to the more essential combination of vital forces that distinguish things and individuals one from the other. Its elements are: _reclining_ . . . _floor_ . . . _fishhook_ . . . _sheaf_. Do not confuse with _spirits_ (Frame 1930).;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 17-4-2007(130): _Captain Hook_ , his **spirit** crushed, is lying on the ground cursing _Wolverine_ who has defeated him with his far superior claws.;2) [[Balaam](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Balaam)] 2-2-2008(57): You're reclining on the floor trying to hook a sheaf with a small hook through the cracks. That you've been doing this for seven hours without success shows your burning **spirit**.
年;year;In an odd fashion, the kanji for **year** joins together the element for _horse_ , on the top, and the right half of the element for _sunglasses_. Think of it as a _horse_ wearing _sunglasses with one of the lenses popped out_. We will use this latter image again, so learn it now and save yourself the trouble later.;1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 21-3-2007(149): A _horse_ wears a pair of _sunglasses with one lens popped out_ after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New **Year**.;2) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 15-4-2008(63): A **horse** wears a **monocle** for New **Year** s to appear dignified for the **year** of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like [descend](../v4/1308.html) (#1308 降).
三;three;And like the Roman numeral III, which triples the numeral I, the kanji for **three** simply triples the single horizontal stroke. In writing it, think of "1 + 2 = 3" (一 + 二 = 三) in order to keep the middle stroke shorter.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 21-7-2007(68): One + two = **three**.;2) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 26-5-2009(49): **THREE** measurements define the female shape: BUST, WAIST, and HIPS. Waist is the smallest, and for most women the HIPS are wider than the chest.
者;someone;_Old man_ . . . _sun_. This key word looks to be difficult because of its proximity to _somebody_. In fact, it is a very common kanji that will cause you no difficulty at all. Its meaning should be seen as the human referent for the abstract noun  "something.";1) [[Shizuru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shizuru)] 24-8-2007(196): I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for **ninja** : 忍者 – i.e. **someone** who **endures** (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍 ). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it's 者 who can 忍 great 拷 !;2) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 20-1-2007(72): Back in the _day_ , the _old man_ used to be **someone**. His name was in the papers and all that. I use CHUCKY from the movie Child's Play as my major alternate meaning for this primitive.
十;ten;Turn this character 45 degrees either way and you have the x used for the Roman numeral **ten**.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 24-7-2007(68): Two needles crossing marks the spot, or you can use the Roman character for **ten** (rotated 45 degrees).;2) [[naur_caraniril](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/naur_caraniril)] 11-10-2008(47): I scared away **ten** vampires with a single cross!
前;in front;We waited to introduce this character until now, even though the pieces have been available for some time, because it helps to reinforce the odd kanji of the last frame. Picture the _butcher_ hacking away with his knife at a slab of meat on his table with a pair of ram's _horns_ placed **in front** of him (or on his head, if you prefer). There is no need to worry about confusing this kanji with that for _before_ (Frame 263), since it will not appear as a primitive in any other character used in this book.;1) [[diracbracket](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/diracbracket)] 26-12-2007(354): When I get _horn_ y my _flesh sword_ sticks out **in front** of me.;2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 25-10-2007(74): If you stand **in front** of a bull's _horns_ , you are asking for your _flesh_ to be _cut_ (or _butchered_ if you prefer).
家;house;This is the full character whose primitive form we learned already. To help a little, this kanji recalls the times when the "domestic" animals were, as the word itself suggests, really kept in the **house**. Hence: _house_ . . . _sow_.;1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 1-11-2006(245): Think of "The Three Little Pigs". There was a _house_ made of straw, another made of sticks, and a third made of bricks, each occupied by a _pig_. So, naturally, _housetop_ over _pig_ means **house** , the central element of that story.;2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 10-2-2008(41): Man, ever hear of cleaning? This **house** is a _pig_ sty.
心;heart;This character, a pictographic representation of the **heart** , is among the most widely used primitives we shall meet.;1) [[munia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/munia)] 25-12-2008(60): (mature content: violence) I hung the **heart** of my victim with a _hook_ and three _drops_ of blood spattered me.;2) [[oRis1024](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/oRis1024)] 15-8-2008(30): **Heart** needs three drops of blood to work.
今;now;The final stroke of this kanji is a rare shape, which we have not met before and will only meet in this character and others that include it as a primitive. We are more accustomed to seeing it straightened out as part of other shapes - for instance, as the second stroke of _mouth_. If you need any help at all with this character, you may picture it as two hands of a clock pointing to what time it is **now**. The element above it, _meeting_ , should easily relate to that image.;1) [[ruuku35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruuku35)] 7-8-2007(230): My MEETING is at 7- but that's **NOW**!;2) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 7-9-2007(32): (re: ruuku35) The _meeting_ is not at _quarter to seven_ but **now**!
下;below;Here we see our famous miraculous _magic wand_ hanging, all on its own, **below** the _ceiling_ , as you probably already guessed would happen. In addition to giving us two new kanji, the two shapes given in this and the preceding frame also serve to fix the use of the primitives for _ceiling_ and _floor_ , by drawing our attention successively to the line standing above and **below** the primitive element to which it is related.;1) [[rakutenka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rakutenka)] 30-6-2007(77): Roots are **below** the ground.;2) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 2-7-2007(48): A _magic wand_ hanging **below** the ceiling.
的;bull´s eye;The elements _white bird_ and _ladle_ easily suggest the image of a **bull's eye** if you imagine a rusty old _ladle_ with a **bull's eye** painted on it in the form of a tiny _white bird_ , who lets out a little "peep" every time you hit the target.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 22-7-2007(223): I managed to hit the bull's eye by throwing my white ladle.;2) [[seanolan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/seanolan)] 10-10-2006(167): A _white_ , _bound up_ , _drop_ in the center is the bull's eye. (why Heisig had to use "ladle" instead of the original two primitives that make up "ladle" I'll never understand!).
物;thing;Cow . . . knot.;1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 18-6-2007(190): The _cow_ 's " **thing** " is tied in a _knot_! ouch.;2) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 3-12-2005(160): A _cow_ is _not_ a **thing**. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and **thing** s are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.
立;stand up;This picture of a vase **standing up** has its meaning extended to represent the general posture of anything **standing up**.;1) [[kitchen_sink](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kitchen_sink)] 14-8-2007(88): A vase that can't **stand up** won't be a vase for long.;2) [[andrewlandry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/andrewlandry)] 30-3-2009(26): This is a real **stand up** vase. It even wears a top hat!
小;little;The sense of **little** that this character represents is not the same as  "a little bit." That meaning comes in the next frame. Here **little** means "small" or "tiny." The image is one of three **little** _drops_ , the first of which (the one in the middle) is written larger so that the kanji has some shape to it. The point of writing it three times is to rub the point in: **little** , **little** , nothing but **little**.;1) [[Harrow](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Harrow)] 3-9-2008(121): A **little** penguin with its wings at its side.;2) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 13-9-2007(37): A depressed child, head low and arms hung low, because he's too **little** to ride the roller coaster.
文;sentence;Under the familiar _top hat_ we see a crisscross pattern or design, like that found on woodwork or garments. This should make an ugly enough image to help remember it. It can be associated with **sentence** by thinking of a **sentence** as a grammatical pattern.;1) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 4-1-2007(183): A twist on greenapple: The teacher puts a tophat on all pupils with gramatically correct **sentence** s, while the rest are left with a big red X on their homework.;2) [[greenapple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/greenapple)] 2-5-2006(60): The teacher in the tophat puts an X on all the grammatically incorrect **sentence** s.
知;know;Dart . . . mouth.;1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 10-7-2006(287): I should _know_. After all, I did graduate from **Dart** **mouth**!;2) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 21-9-2006(133): [know, wisdom] [An arrow 矢 like mouth 口 ] If you **know** the answers, they will fly like _dart_ s from your _mouth_.
入;enter;This character is meant to be a picture of someone walking leftwards, putting one leg forward in order to **enter** someplace. Since the  "in" side of a character is the left, it should be easy to remember the writing of this character.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(69): Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive, using the image of going through a door, even one that stands alone with the frame and no wall around, helps flesh out the primitive “enter”.;2) [[vgambit](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vgambit)] 26-12-2008(36): Gordon Freeman **enters** the Black Mesa corporation's headquarters on that fateful day, after starting up a game of Half-Life (this kanji looks exactly like the lambda from the logo when written).
作;make;Person . . . saw.;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 26-2-2007(152): _Mr T._ 's favorite magazine is **Make**. He loves to **make** things. But he's a purist: he only uses _saws_ , no power tools.;2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-4-2007(70): When the A-Team crash lands on a deserted island, _Mr. T_ salvages a _saw_ from the wreckage and says, "I don't know about y'all foos, but I'm gonna **make** a raft.".
月;month;This character is actually a picture of the moon, with the two horizontal lines representing the left eye and mouth of the mythical "man in the moon." (Actually, the Japanese see a hare in the moon, but it is a little farfetched to find one in the kanji.) And one **month** , of course, is one cycle of the moon.;1) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 19-5-2008(157): A **month** is longer than a day.;2) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 21-3-2007(60): Am I the only one who sees this as someone sticking their ass in the air "mooning" someone (two cheeks of the butt and the legs coming off of it)? The Moon meaning connects well to the meaning of **month** , considering that **month** s were traditionally measured by the phases of the moon. Also, the mooning "ass" part of it connects well to Hesig's seemingly unconnected "flesh" or "part of the body" meaning (when used in primitive form).
書;write;The sage talks rapidly with his _tongue wagging in his mouth_ , while the _brush_ of the scribe runs apace to **write** down the master 'swords.;1) [[jinka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jinka)] 27-4-2006(213): Make sure you practice **writing** kanji with a _brush_ every _day_ before the _sun_ goes down.;2) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 28-10-2007(36): The calligrapher had a peculiar habit: when using her _brush_ to **write** , she would stick out her _tongue_ , just slightly.
学;study;The _child_ in the little red _schoolhouse_ is there for one reason only: to **study**. Anyone who has gone through the schooling system knows well enough that **study** is one thing and _learning_ quite another again. In the kanji, too, the character for _learning  _(Frame 616) has nothing to do with the _schoolhouse_.;1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 12-1-2007(78): In the _school house_ there are _kids_ always **studying**. (BTW, atomiton, this is NOT 字 ).;2) [[gwadonna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gwadonna)] 9-8-2008(51): Children in schoolhouses are there to **study** , nothing else!!!
合;fit;The kanji for **fit** reads literally, top to bottom, as a _meeting_ of _mouths_  \- which is a rather descriptive way of speaking of a romantic kiss. We all know what happens when there is no meeting of minds and when people's ideas don't **fit**  with one another. But this kanji invites us to imagine what would happened to the romance of a certain unfortunate couple whose _mouths_ didn't **fit**.;1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 13-9-2007(159): I wouldn't mind a _meeting_ of _mouths_ with her, she's really **fit** !;2) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 13-7-2007(102): He had such a big _mouth_ that he could easily **fit** _one_ whole _umbrella_ in it.
山;mountain;Note the clearer outline of a triangular **mountain** here.;1) [[the40pancakes](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/the40pancakes)] 14-4-2009(108): YOU CAN'T POSSIBLY NEED A MNEMONIC FOR THIS!!!!;2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(67): Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive this element appears equally as well at the top or bottom of the kanjis (besides appearing to the left). Since a **mountain** often brings to mind towering peaks, I will consider it implied that the element is placed at the top of the kanji. When this primitive appears at the bottom, I will arrange my story in a way that other elements are said to be at the very top of the **mountain** (see FRAME 775 for an example).
後;behind;Line . . . cocoon . . . walking legs.;1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 16-12-2006(228): Column of walking legs (caterpillar) getting into a cocoon, about to leave its past self **behind**.;2) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 30-5-2007(75): **after** a grub _goes_ through the _cocoon_ stage, it leaves its _walking legs_ **behind** for a life of flight.
目;eye;Here again, if we round out the corners of this kanji and curve the middle strokes upwards and downwards respectively, we get something resembling an **eye**.;1) [[d3kuma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/d3kuma)] 13-7-2009(223): 目 _ 目 .;2) [[kylemanning](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kylemanning)] 22-11-2007(92): There are 3 sections. Imagine the outer two being the whites of your **eye**. The middle is the pupil. Fill it in with imaginary color.
持;hold;Fingers . . . Buddhist temple.;1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 19-8-2007(183): At the BUDDHIST TEMPLE you'll see wonderous things, such as the priest that can **HOLD** himself upside down with just a FINGER.;2) [[Tweenk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tweenk)] 10-4-2007(88): In Kyaiktiyo, there is rocking stone which sits on the edge of a cliff, and there is a _Buddhist temple_ built on the top of it. You can rock the stone by pushing it with your _finger_ , but it still **holds** in place. It's true, see here: <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyaiktiyo>.
居;reside;_Flag_ . . . _old_. Do not confuse with _dwell_ (Frame 1027).;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 23-8-2007(178): A humongous _American flag_ in Florida marks the place where all the _old_ people **reside**.;2) [[nilfisq](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nilfisq)] 16-9-2007(131): It is an _old_ tradition that people plant a _flag_ on places where decide to **reside** , this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. [set](../v4/1064.html) (#1064 据).
無;nothingness;This character is the Japanese character for the supreme philosophical principle of much Oriental thought: **nothingness**. Make use of the oaken _tub_ from the previous frame, and add to that the _oven fire_ at the bottom.;1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 17-9-2007(278): When I enter the _wooden tub_ heated by _flames_ in the onsen, I can let all my worries slip away and be submerged into **nothingness**.;2) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 30-12-2006(40): In a hot tub you can relax and have your stress vanish into **nothingness**.
様;Esq.;The abbreviation **Esq.** will help associate this character with the honorific form of address to which it belongs. Its elements are: _tree_ . . . _sheep_ . . . _grains of rice_. Note that the final vertical stroke in the element for _sheep_ is extended to form the first stroke for _grains of rice_.;1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 6-4-2007(321): Here we have the requirements to be counted among the ranks of the noble **Esq.** You must posses a _forested_ estate, herds of _sheep_ , and granary full of _grains of rice_.;2) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 5-9-2007(165): This is **-Sama** , a generic high term of respect for someone in an unusual profession. If you met a person that created a _wooden_ _sheep_ that was squeezing a single _grain of rice_ out of its ass, you'd definitely call that person **-sama**. Because that is impressive.
意;idea;Sound . . . heart.;1) [[onsen_monkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/onsen_monkey)] 4-10-2006(325): When you get a good **IDEA** you get excited and you can hear the SOUND of your HEART, it's pounding so hard.;2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 11-10-2005(58): Picture someone who's just had a great **idea** , but in place of a blinking light bulb over their head, you see a _heart_ thumping with great _noise_. Imagine the greater the **idea** , the louder the _sound_ of the beating _heart_.
地;ground;_Soil_ and a _scorpion_ (an  "earth animal"). This is, of course, the full character from which the primitive for **ground** derives.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(161): Picture the **ground** as an extent of _soil_ where _scorpions_ are buried like land mines. Imagine a sign post saying 'no trespassing, _scorpion_ mines' if that helps, and how it is dangerous to walk there.;2) [[bigspenderJ](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bigspenderJ)] 7-2-2007(77): The soil is littered with scorpions everywhere and no ones dares put their foot on the **ground**.
御;honorable;Line . . . wholesale.;1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 9-6-2007(207): An **honorable** man will not try to cut in front of the _line_ at the _wholesale_ stamp store. (Imagine just how much honor it takes facing those long lines at the post office!).;2) [[ergerg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ergerg)] 5-5-2007(68): In front of the COLUMNS of the Capitol, the **HONORABLE** congressmen can be bought WHOLESALE.
屋;roof;_Flag_ . . . _climax_. Note that this kanji has no relation to the drawing of a  "roof" used in the primitive for _house_.;1) [[samuize](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/samuize)] 27-7-2007(219): Flag at the climax (highest point) of a castle **roof**.;2) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 10-4-2007(113): A couple climaxing on the **roof** , draped in the American flag. The neighbors are mortified and call the landlady…
度;degrees;This key word refers to a gradation of measurement, not to academic diplomas. Its primitives: _caverns_ . . . _crotch_.;1) [[jimsublimeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jimsublimeman)] 4-12-2007(225): The _cavern refugees_ are so poor that they can't afford thermometers. So, the menfolk expose their _crotches_ inside the cavern, and approximate the temperature in **degrees** from how shrivelled everything looks downstairs…;2) [[jameserb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jameserb)] 3-5-2008(64): The cave is twenty **degrees** cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.
同;same;The primitives in this kanji show us _one_ and _mouth_ under a _hood_. Let us take the key word to connote the **sameness** that characterizes the life in community of the monk. They all have the **same** habits, including the "habit" they wear on their backs. Here we see the monk's _cowl_ , drawn down over the eyes so that all you can see when you look at him is a _mouth_. But since monks also speak their prayers in common, it is but a short step to think of _one mouth_ under a _hood_ as the kanji for the **sameness** of monastic life.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(215): Muslim women wearing veils (HOOD) all look the **same** , you can just see ONE MOUTH and very little else.;2) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 5-9-2007(84): Imagine monks wandering around the monastery. Covered in their _hoods_ and chanting as if with _one mouth_ they all look the **same** !
不;negative;You may play with the primitives of this kanji as you wish ( _ceiling_ . . . _person_ . . . _a drop of_ ), _but_ you will probably find that its simplicity, and its frequency, make it easy to remember just as it is.;1) [[laner36](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laner36)] 24-9-2007(194): [Smithsonian] Scene: _Mr. T_ hanging from the _ceiling_ being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a _drop_ of saliva) in the torturer's face, he says "Negative".;2) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 20-8-2007(45): _One below_ zero is a **negative** number.
実;reality;House . . . bonsai.;1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 27-12-2006(239): Bonsais are grown in a house, away from the harsh **reality** of the real world where they wouldn't survive.;2) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 12-12-2007(104): On this rather boring 'big brother' type **reality** show, they have locked up _bonsai_ inside a _house_ and everyone is watching them on TV 24x7. The viewers have to vote on which bonsai shall remain in the house and which one has to leave.
話;tale;That the _words_ of the _tongue_ should come to mean a **tale** is clear from the etymology: a **_tale_** is something  "talked," not something read from a book.;1) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 22-7-2007(178): **Tale** s are always spoken, not written, and because of this, _words_ fly out of your _tongue_ , rather than your pen.;2) [[Rivvie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rivvie)] 28-1-2008(55): **Tale** s are _spoken words_ , passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a _thousand mouths_.
身;somebody;The key word **somebody** was chosen to convey the double meaning of this kanji: body and person. Its composition is based on the _nose_ (which, you will recall, is also the kanji for _oneself_ ). The extension of the bottom and far right strokes of that element, together with the unusual diagonal stroke, forms the pictograph of **somebody** with a prominent paunch.;1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 8-12-2006(230): **Somebody** was just looking for you. He had a long _nose_ that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is some _body_ rather than [someone](../v4/1256.html) (#1256 者) is that the story is full of _body_ descriptions.;2) [[greenapple](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/greenapple)] 16-3-2006(56): **Somebody** was just looking for you. He had a long nose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face.
所;place;Door . . . ax.;1) [[dihutenosa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dihutenosa)] 11-9-2007(149): You outsiders better learn your **place**! An _axe_ stuck in the _door_ when you get home is a pretty good indicator that this might not be the best **place** for you.;2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 23-7-2007(94): A **place** for everything and everything in its **place**. To the right of the _door_ is the standard **place** for the _axe_.
先;before;Take this key word in its physical, not its temporal, sense (even though it refers to both). If you have a _cow_ with _human legs_ , as the elements show us here, it can only be because you have two people in a _cow_ -suit. I always thought I'd prefer to be the one standing **before** , rather than the one that holds up the rear and becomes the "butt" of everyone's laughter.;1) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 20-10-2007(232): I've never seen a _cow_ with _human legs_ **before**!;2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 9-6-2008(158): Nasty story but it keeps the meaning true to the kanji. "BEFORE you stick it in a COW and SPREAD the legs (the bottom stroke of this cow looks like two legs) make sure she has HUMAN LEGS"————-sorry, I'll remove if I get enough reports, but will keep if I get more stars.
力;power;With a little imagination, one can see a muscle in this simple, two-stroke character meaning **power**.;1) [[lankydan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lankydan)] 23-8-2007(140): I always refer to the **power** of the _KATAKANA "KA"_.;2) [[stshores24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stshores24)] 10-7-2008(39): I have a very **power** ful _muscle カ_ in my driveway!
五;five;As with _four_ , we shall postpone learning the primitive elements that make up this character. Note how the general principle we just learned in the preceding frame applies to the writing of the character for **five**.;1) [[NooNoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NooNoo)] 11-4-2008(236): 三 + two vertical lines = 5.;2) [[Branduil](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Branduil)] 25-2-2006(36): This Kanji looks like a "3" Kanji with two added vertical lines. 3+2= 5.
明;bright;Among nature's **bright** lights, there are two that the biblical myth has God set in the sky: the _sun_ to rule over the day and the _moon_ to rule the night. Each of them has come to represent one of the common connotations of this key word: the _sun_ , the **bright** insight of the clear thinker, and the _moon_ , the **bright** intuition of the poet and the seer (see frame 13).;1) [[ablindmouse](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ablindmouse)] 28-8-2007(330): The sun makes the moon **bright**.;2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 21-7-2007(58): The sun and the moon are **bright** est objects in the day and night, respectively.
代;substitute;Person . . . arrow.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 18-10-2005(178): " _Mister T_ **substitute** s an _arrow_ for a toothpick" – The keyword meaning is to replace something with something else, to act for another, to represent. It's best to stick to the first meaning, because the last two are very close to "mediator" which will come in frame 1761. The idea here is that the _arrow_ is not a toothpick, neither it is changed into one, but it can **substitute** for one.;2) [[bkvogel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bkvogel)] 31-7-2008(60): Mr. T shot the **substitute** teacher with an arrow.
然;sort of thing;The key word in this frame refers to a suffix that gives the word before it an adjectival quality, hence we refer to it as " **sort of thing**. " Reverting to the time when dog was more widely eaten than it is today (See frame 127), we see here a large cauldron boiling over an _oven flame_ with the _flesh_ of a _chihuahua_ being thrown into the whole concoction to make it into a  "hot- diggity, dog-diggity" **sort of thing**.;1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 11-10-2007(322): _Flesh_ of a _dog_ over a cooking fire = "hotdog". There are all **sorts of things** in _hot dogs_. Believe me, you don't want to know what **sort of things** . Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr's. Thanks!).;2) [[ziggr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ziggr)] 9-9-2006(98): There are all **sorts of things** in _hot dogs_. (I use _hot dog_ for this primitive ( _meat_ of a _dog_ over a _cooking fire_ ). I swear I can actually see the 月 here as a hot dog, with its slight curve and grill marks.).
通;traffic;_Chop-seal_ . . . _utilize_ . . . _road_. By combining the first two primitives into a single image, you will be able to use that image in a few instances later, one of which comes immediately.;1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-2-2008(328): I bounce down the _road_ on my _pogo stick_ , easily getting through the dense **traffic**. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a _chop-seal_ is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could _utilize_ it as a _pogo stick_ ). [Edit: _pogo stick_ also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530].;2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 7-7-2006(45): Building on gorgon's story I now change mine to a much more silly and rememberable one. The Chinese police is using a helicopter to check and regulate the **traffic**. Hanging from the helicopter is a huge _chopseal_ that they _utilize_ to mark some of the cars that are causing trouble on the _road_.
水;water;This character, which looks a bit like a snowflake, is actually a pictograph of **water**  \- not any particular body of water or movement of water, but simply the generic name for **water**. Should you have any difficulty remembering it, simply think of a _walking stick_ being dropped vertically into the **water** , sending _droplets_ out in all four directions. Then all you need to learn is how to write it in proper order.;1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 8-11-2007(67): The kanji for **water** is an abstract primitive itself, so unless one is willing to break down its etymological development, it should just simply be memorized by strokes, constructing a story is not necessarily useful unless it strongly denotes its shape (I find that Heisig's story doesn't do this).;2) [[CandyCane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CandyCane)] 5-10-2008(54): For those having issues with this* "A 7K foot pool of **water** " Notice it looks like a 7, and a K. Might have to practice writing it a few times.
聞;hear;_Gates_ . . . _ear_. Compare the story you invented for the kanji meaning _listen_ (Frame 890).;1) [[laxxy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laxxy)] 3-10-2006(195): Press your ear to the gates and see if you can **hear** what is going on inside.;2) [[ambrokusa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ambrokusa)] 2-4-2007(50): To distinguish from listen, you **hear** someone at the door (gate).
長;long;In line with the story of the preceding frame, the _hair_ that needs the _hairpin_ is **long**.;1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 7-10-2007(152): The Geisha with **long** _hair_ uses an ornate lacquered _hairpin_ to bundle it all up.;2) [[Shibo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Shibo)] 22-6-2008(74): The top of this one reminds me of the staple primitive. So here's my story: The girl's hair was so **long** that she had to use _staples_ instead of _hairpins_. It worked, but stapling her hair to her head was kinda painful.
少;few;First we need to look at the fourth stroke, the _drop_ at the bottom that has been extended into a longer diagonal stroke leaning left. This happens because a single, isolated drop will NEVER appear beneath its relative primitive in its normal size, for fear it would drop off and get lost. As for the meaning, let the tiny _drop_ indicate a further belittling of what is already _little_ \- thus making it a **few** of something _little_.;1) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 6-2-2008(129): Only a **few** people can make an ugly face like that.;2) [[DrWarrior12](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrWarrior12)] 3-8-2007(60): **Few** usually refers to three. To emphasize three, we underline the three drops in little.
第;No.;The key word **No.** is the abbreviation for  "number." Its elements: _bamboo_ . . . _dollar sign_.;1) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 5-3-2007(214): The **No.** 1 currency in the world is the _dollar_. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the _bamboo_ represent the **No.** 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order ( _bamboo_ on top and the _dollar_ on the bottom) is really a look at the future.;2) [[WithLoveFromExIA](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/WithLoveFromExIA)] 10-1-2009(101): The **No.** 1 currency may at one time have been the dollar, but since the economic slowdown the _weak dollar_ has been overtaken by currencies from _bamboo_ growing countries. (Thanks to Johnnyltn for the idea.) Using the alternate writing of the dollar primitive as weak dollar.
感;emotion;Mouths . . . marching . . . heart.;1) [[szreter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/szreter)] 15-2-2008(283): **Emotion** is a _march of mouths_ inside your _heart_ telling you what to feel.;2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 17-7-2008(130): Strong **EMOTION** S don't stay hidden. They march right out of one's _heart_ (below) and out _one_ 's _mouth_ (shouted, snarled, or gently whispered - depending on exactly what kind of **emotion** it is!).
世;generation;We generally consider one **generation** as a period of thirty (or _ten_ plus _ten_ plus _ten_ ) years. If you look at this kanji in its completed form - not in its stroke order - you will see three _tens_. When writing it, think of the lower horizontal lines as  "addition" lines written under numbers to add them up. Thus: _ten_ "plus" _ten_ "plus" _ten_ = thirty. Actually, it's a lot easier doing it with a pencil than reading it in a book.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 21-7-2007(112): 3 tens = **generation**.;2) [[CarlKenner](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CarlKenner)] 5-7-2007(71): They **SAY** a **generation** is _ten_ + _ten_ + _ten_ years, with the big first _ten_ providing a _grounding_ , and the next _ten_ providing a little more _grounding_ for the final _ten_. But I wish the next **generation** didn't always **SAY** " **yo!** ". (ON reading is SEI, KUN reading is yo).
空;empty;Hole . . . craft.;1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 4-6-2006(132): The _craft_ of creating a _black hole_ is in creating an **emptiness** which can attract things.;2) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 7-11-2007(76): Hole- craft is the way of making **empty** spaces, like the sky.
四;four;This character is composed of two primitive elements, _mouth_ and _human legs_ , both of which we will meet in the coming lessons. Assuming that you already knew how to write this kanji, we will pass over the "story" connected with it until later. Note how the second stroke is written left-to-right and then top- to-bottom. This is consistent with what we have already seen in the first three numbers and leads us to a general principle that will be helpful when we come to more complicated kanji later on: write north-to-south, west-to-east, northwest-to-southeast.;1) [[tomb771](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tomb771)] 9-2-2007(115): **FOUR** year-olds often put their FOOT (human legs) in their MOUTH - but they are too young to realize.;2) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 21-3-2007(42): I imagine a giant devouring a human in **four** bites. First the giant bites off the person's head, then he bites the torso, then from the waist to the knees, and finally the giant plucks up the remaining portion of the human legs into his mouth. See the **four** th bite falling in there?
理;logic;We first referred to this character back in frame 185, to which you might want to return to have a peek. The image of **logic** we are given is something like a central _jewel_ in a _computer_ , like the _jewels_ in old clocks that keep them running smoothly. Try to picture yourself making your way through all the rams and roms and approaching this shining _jewel_ , a chorus of voice sand a blast of trumpets in the background heralding the great seat of all- knowing **logic**.;1) [[Birdsong](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Birdsong)] 26-4-2007(341): The king of **LOGIC** is the computer.;2) [[johanvg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johanvg)] 16-7-2006(33): Computers are ruled by **logic** (it is the king of computers).
田;rice field;Another pictograph, this kanji looks like a bird's-eye view of a **rice field** divided into four plots. Be careful when writing this character to get the order of the strokes correct. You will find that it follows perfectly the principle stated in frame 4.;1) [[Chisaku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Chisaku)] 30-6-2007(114): A **rice field** divided into four parts.;2) [[Kosmo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Kosmo)] 17-5-2008(41): _Ten_ people use their _mouths_ to eat the yield of the **rice fields**.
主;lord;A man's home is his castle, goes the proverb from an age where it was the male who was **lord** of the household. Fundamentally, it means only that every one of us is a bit (or _drop_ ) of a _king_ in our own environment. As for the positioning of the elements, if you take care to  "read off" the primitives in this way, you won't end up putting the _drop_ down below, where it turns the kanji into a jewel.;1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 22-10-2007(196): A **lord** is a little _drop_ down from _King_ in hierarchy.;2) [[Spoonz](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spoonz)] 15-2-2009(79): A **lord** only has a drop of the king's power.
名;name;Perhaps you have heard of the custom, still preserved in certain African tribes, of a father creeping into the tent or hut of his newborn child on the night of the child's birth, to whisper into its ear the **name** he has chosen for it, before making his choice public. It is an impressive **naming** custom and fits in tidily with the way this character is constructed: _evening_ . . . _mouth_. At _evening_ time, a _mouth_ pronounces the **name** that will accompany one throughout life.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 24-7-2007(165): In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your **name** so that people can recognise you.;2) [[panikbuton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/panikbuton)] 20-1-2008(81): In the evening, her sweet mouth whispered my **name**.
口;mouth;Like several of the first characters we shall learn, the kanji for **mouth** is a clear pictograph. Since there are no circular shapes in the kanji, the square must be used to depict the circle.;1) [[currynrice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/currynrice)] 30-6-2007(110): Looks like a huge open **mouth**.;2) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 8-11-2008(21): When you sneeze, your **MOUTH** forms a square, and you make a noise that sounds like (KUCHI).
面;mask;Imagine a **mask** over your head with _eyes_ peeping out from all over the head, a _hundred_ in all (the element for _eye_ displacing the fifth stroke of that for _hundred_ ).;1) [[Zactacular](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Zactacular)] 4-10-2007(147): When Jim Carrey puts on **The **Mask**** , he can make it seem like he has _100 eyes_ popping out of his head.;2) [[phauna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phauna)] 27-2-2008(106): If you're wearing a **mask** , a _hundred_ _eyes_ can look at you but none of them will know who you are.
場;location;Soil . . . piggy bank.;1) [[vosmiura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/vosmiura)] 30-5-2007(259): You're looking for a good **location** to bury your _piggy bank_ savings. It has to be in some soft _soil_ that's easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to rememger like this kanji.;2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 27-1-2008(86): Don't confuse with [place](../v4/1127.html) (#1127 所). Think of **location** not as a single fixed spot, but as the act of locating. You've buried your _piggy bank_ in the _dirt_ in your backyard, but you can't remember where. You frantically dig everywhere in a process of **location** to find your piggy bank.
顔;face;Lad . . . head.;1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 12-7-2007(168): The _lad_ jumps off the cliff, breaks his _head_ , and smashes his **face**.;2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 10-4-2008(54): When I was a _lad_ , a pretty **face** was all it took for someone to get in my _head_ , and I'd fill _pages_ of lovelorn letters to them.
君;old boy;The somewhat highbrow British term of address is chosen hereto represent the kanji for a form of address used towards one's juniors. It is composed of: _mop_ . . . _mouth_.;1) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 9-3-2011(224): There's a tendency in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. "Well **old boy** ," a senpai might say, "If you did as much work with the _mop_ as you do with your _mouth,_ you would have been done an hour ago".;2) [[stefanot](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stefanot)] 22-1-2007(69): The Beatles, english **old boy** s, had hairs like _mop_ and a good singing _mouth_.
成;turn into;Let the phrase " **turn into** " suggest some sort of a magical change. What happens here is that the _parade_ marching down main street **turns into** a _dagger_ -throwing bout between competing bands. Note how only one stroke has to be added to make the change.;1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 19-2-2008(248): It only takes a single stroke of a _dagger_ for a _parade_ to **TURN INTO** a bloodbath.;2) [[usis35](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/usis35)] 4-11-2007(26): The gay parade suddenly TURNED INTO a DAGGER throwing fight.
白;white;The color **white** is a mixture of all the primary colors, both for pigments and for light, as we see when a prism breaks up the rays of the sun. Hence, a single _drop_ of _sun_ spells **white**.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 21-7-2007(130): A **white** ray is a drop of sun.;2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 29-10-2007(61): Even a small drop (') of the sun ( 日 ) would make you see nothing but **white**.
考;consider;_Old man_ . . . _slingshot_. Remember: you already have kanji for _discriminating_ (Frame 521), _deliberation_ (Frame 692), and _think_ (Frame 651).;1) [[kyldyyr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kyldyyr)] 17-11-2005(224): Before shooting an _old man_ with a _slingshot_ , one shold carefully **consider** the possible consequences.;2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 14-3-2007(82): Even though he had the _old man_ Mr. Wilson within the sights of his _slingshot_ , Dennis the Menace **considered** what he was doing and stopped.
道;road-way;The key word carries both the sense of a **road** for transit and a **way** or method of doing something, but the former is better for forming an image. The primitives read: the _neck_ of a _road_. Think of a crowded **road-way** where traffic has come to a standstill - what we commonly refer to as a  "bottle _neck_. ";1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 5-2-2008(198): When we go out on the **ROAD-WAY** , we often risk our own _necks_ (that's why I take the train! ).;2) [[whistler11](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/whistler11)] 19-12-2005(39): Watch as a villianous fiend stretches a poor damsel's _neck_ over a dusty _road_. Her ear pressed to the ground, she can hear the rumble of a carriage thundering down the roadway. Will the hero save her in time? Or will her _neck_ be ground into the _road_ , spilling it's precious contents into the dust?
正;correct;"A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step," says the Chinese proverb. Here we see _one footprint_ , complementing that proverb with the sound advice that if the first step is not made **correctly** , the whole point of the journey will be forfeited. This is the ideal that teachers are supposed to have in **correcting** their students, and parents in **correcting** their children.;1) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 19-10-2007(223): If you do it **correct** on the _first_ attempt you can _stop_.;2) [[tom2000](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tom2000)] 4-8-2009(43): My (Japanese) wife tells me that Japanese people use this kanji to tally up numbers (instead of 4 vertical lines and a diagonal across). I remember this one by writing the kanji while counting out the strokes to myself and saying this is the **correct** way to tally numbers.
郎;son;Halo . . . city walls.;1) [[aircawn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aircawn)] 11-2-2007(262): The _daughter_ is a good girl that grows up to be a woman. The **son** is a _good_ boy that grows up to defend the _city walls_.;2) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 1-1-2007(19): Just like a daughter ( 娘 ) is good woman, **son** is good too, and stays safely inside city walls so as not to give his parents reason to worry.
当;hit;Little . . . broom.;1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 9-4-2007(249): Some mothers use a _small broom_ to **hit** their children when they misbehave.;2) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 25-2-2007(53): [hit, right, appropriate, himself] If you're old enough, this is a pictograph of an Atari joystick (which, BTW, got its name from this word/kanji). You can also think of how an Atari joystick is like a _small_ _broom_ with which you can **hit** and sweep off the enemies from the screen…
男;man;_Rice fields_ . . . _power_. This character is the gender-specific **man** , not the generic human _person_ of frame 951.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(212): Male is seen here as muscles working in the field, in other words working in the rice fields is the work of the male who are usually stronger. This is more or less the meaning of the original Chinese character.;2) [[Callooh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Callooh)] 3-9-2007(107): When it comes to choosing a **MAN** , I prefer _brains_ over _muscles_.
外;outside;On the left, the primitive for _evening_ , and on the right, that for the _magic wand_. Now, as every magician worth his abracadabra knows, bringing your _magic wand_ out into the _evening_ air makes your magic much more powerful than if you were to stay indoors. Hence, _evening_ and _magic wand_ takes you naturally **outside**.;1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 7-7-2008(134): A young magician likes to practice **outside** in the _evening_ with his _magic wand_ (as opposed to the old magician who wakes _early_ to practice with his _wand_ in [eminent](../v4/51.html) (#51 卓)).;2) [[jondesousa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jondesousa)] 19-6-2006(77): **Outside** in the dark of evening, only a magic wand can help you.
国;country;Jewels . . . pent in.;1) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 12-1-2008(127): In my **country** (England) the crown _jewels_ are kept _pent-in_ in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also _pent- in_ (probably for trying to steal those _jewels_ ).;2) [[genbaku](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/genbaku)] 11-1-2008(95): Just think of Japan, a **country** which is like a jewel but historically very enclosed.
会;meeting;_Meeting_ . . . _wall_. This is the full character for **meeting** , from which the abbreviated primitive that we met back in lesson 12 gets its name.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(194): At the local company they have a very gory way of getting rid of incompetent personnel : they arrange a business **meeting** in a very special room where the walls are … **meeting**. Not surprisingly the boss is never present at these **meeting** s, he's the one who pushes the button that sets the walls in motion.;2) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 5-11-2007(102): The only thing created in most **meeting** s is a lot of hot air. Imagine a _cloud of it rising_ to the _roof_.
取;take;Ear . . . crotch.;1) [[Rakushun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rakushun)] 17-5-2007(257): You put your ear next to a womans crotch…and somehow, from it, you hear the words "Take me….".;2) [[cjon256](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cjon256)] 1-5-2009(136): Fuaburisu's with a twist: You know that classic trick where someone pretends to **take** something out of an someone else's _ear_ (such as a coin). Instead of a cigarette or a pen he pulls the person’s _crotch_ out of their ear. Very painful!
新;new;Red pepper . . . ax.;1) [[gorgon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gorgon)] 27-2-2006(207): (I don't like the 'red pepper plant' primative so I just go for _standing atop a tree_ ). Here we have the woodcutter _standing atop a tree_ waving his brand **new** _axe_. "Look what I got for christmas, yippee!".;2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 16-10-2005(66): Axe-man grows a patch of _red pepper plants_ in his back garden. He rubs _red peppers_ on the edge of his _axes_ , and this seems to keep them sharp like brand **new**.
風;wind;_Windy_ . . . _drops of_ . . . _insects_. Hint: think of the last two primitives as representing a swarm of _gnats_ , those tiny _drops of_ pesky _insects_.;1) [[Ceryn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ceryn)] 16-4-2008(137): They say that when an INSECT flaps its wings even the single DROP of **WIND** that it creates is sometimes enough to create a hurricane on the other side of the Earth.;2) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 29-1-2008(82): The **WIND** usually carries things around in it - _drops_ of rain or snow, and lots of _insects_.
神;gods;Altar . . . monkey.;1) [[Floatingweed5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Floatingweed5)] 10-9-2007(108): The **Gods** are gathered around debating Zeus' latest purchase for Mount Olympus. A huge and extremely kitsch gilded altar in the shape of giant "speak no evil" monkey. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again .;2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 30-12-2006(107): Hinduism has many **gods** , not just one God. One of the most famous of these **gods** is Hanuman the _monkey_. Many _altars_ are dedicated to him.
動;move;Heavy . . . muscle.;1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 4-7-2006(132): Even though the furniture is _heavy_ , it'll be easy to **move** with all the _muscles_ that he has.;2) [[kumakuma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/kumakuma)] 6-7-2008(91): His MUSCLES are so HEAVY, he barely can **move** …thats ironic.
部;section;Muzzle . . . city walls.;1) [[Copycatken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Copycatken)] 28-6-2006(155): Within the _city walls_ , this **section** of town was so noisy that we had to _muzzle_ them up.;2) [[stehr](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stehr)] 22-11-2007(34): " **Section** 8 housing" is a way to _muzzle_ the impoverished people who are unable to pay rent but want to live inside the _city walls_.
向;yonder;Something referred to as "over **yonder** " is usually far off in the distance and barely within sight - like a wee _drop_ in the distance - and is usually an expression used in giving directions or pointing something out. Hence this kanji begins with a _drop_. Then we find a sort of transparent _helmet_ with no eyes or nose, but only a prominent _mouth_ under it, obviously an extraterrestrial. And what is it jabbering on about with its _mouth_ open like that? Why, about his spaceship way over **yonder** with its fuel tank on empty.;1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 5-9-2007(142): Look over **yonder** ! That tiny _dot_ is robin _hood_ at the _mouth_ of his secret cave !;2) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 22-3-2008(73): There was an old woman named Wanda,// Who wanted to make herself blonder.// She covered her _くち_ // With a _glass hood_ from Gucci// And _drop_ ped some hair dye on from **yonder**.
夜;night;First of all, be sure not to confuse the connotations of **night** with those of _evening_ (Frame 114) and _nightbreak_ (Frame 30). Its elements: _top hat_ . . . _person_ . . . _walking legs_ . . . _drop_.;1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 25-4-2007(216): Actually, the lower-right primitive isn't quite "walking legs." It's a little more like "evening" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for **night** as: _evening_ plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the _top hat_ which my special _person_ is wearing out on the town…;2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 18-10-2005(86): Here we have _Mister T_ sleepwalking, wearing a _top hat_ as if he was the ambassador of the **night** , walking, and walking and walking on his tired _walking legs_ , until he _drops_ (back into his bed).
内;inside;_Person_ . . . _belt_. Note that we cannot use the primitive meaning of _hood_ here because the _person_ runs THROUGH the element, not under it.;1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 11-7-2008(135): _Mr. T_ 's new _belt_ is huge! When he's **inside** it, his feet no longer touch the ground!;2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 2-9-2008(118): A seat _belt_ keeps a _person_ **inside** the vehicle.
青;blue;Grow up . . . moon.;1) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 6-2-2008(147): "Once in a **blue** _moon_ " refers to a rare event. But originally "blue moon" refers to a full moon, in other words a fully _grown-up_ moon. Whether once a month is rare or not depends on what we're talking about, but that happens to be the origin of the expression.;2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 4-3-2007(104): The last time I saw a **blue** _moon_ was in my **youth** when I was _growing up_.
相;inter-;The prefix **inter-** stirs up associations of cooperation among people. From there we read off the elements: _tree_ . . . _eye_. With only a slight leap of the imagination, those two words call to mind the scriptural proverb about first taking the block of timber out of one's own _eye_ before helping your neighbors with the splinter in theirs. What more useful rule for **inter-** human relationships, and what more useful tool for remembering this kanji!;1) [[ashman63](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ashman63)] 25-3-2008(225): The prime minister is having **inter-** course behind that _tree_! All you can see are his _eyes_ poking out from the righthand-side of the _tree_.;2) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 8-4-2008(94): ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. "Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb _trees_ to _eye_ each other's aspects and **inter-** act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government _ministers_ , with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck ( 首 , [neck](../v4/70.html) (#70 首)) becoming the prime _minister_ [「首相](midori://search?text=「首相) (しゅしょう)".
体;body;Person . . . book.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 28-10-2005(133): _Mister T_ works out his **body** (body-building), using two piles of _books_ (i.e. an exercise that can be done at home with two chairs, similar to push- ups but working mostly the shoulders, trapezius and triceps).;2) [[pageturner1988](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pageturner1988)] 14-1-2008(53): Mr. T works out his **body** then rips a book apart to test is **body**. His favorite to destroy is Dianetics.
眼;eyeball;Eye . . . silver.;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(156): T-1000. <http://clicknothing.typepad.com/Images_Posts_2006/T1000.jpg>.;2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 17-9-2006(102): **_Eye_ balls** made of _silver_. That's what they use to play pachinko with, isn't it?
木;tree;Here we see a pictograph of a **tree** , showing the main trunk in the long vertical stroke and the boughs in the long horizontal stroke. The final two strokes sweep down in both directions to indicate the roots. Although it may look similar at first sight to the kanji for _water_ (Frame 137), the order in which it is written is completely different and this affects its final appearance.;1) [[liosama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/liosama)] 28-6-2008(137): If you need a story for a **tree** , then you need to be hit by one.;2) [[beth266](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/beth266)] 2-8-2009(18): Pictograph of a **tree**.
味;flavor;When a tree has _not yet_ finished growing, it produces fruit with a full **flavor**. When the official taster (the professional _mouth_ to the left) determines that full flavor has been reached, the tree is pruned back so that it remains permanently _not yet_ grown. A neat little agricultural trick and an easy to way see the sense of **flavor** hidden in this character.;1) [[lilpea](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lilpea)] 17-8-2007(251): My _mouth_ has _not yet_ swallowed the food because the **flavor** is so delicious that I keep chewing it.;2) [[PeterJD](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PeterJD)] 6-4-2008(134): To enjoy a food's **FLAVOR** , it must be in one's MOUTH but NOT YET swallowed.
僕;me;This key word is yet another synonym for "I," somewhat more familiar in tone. As a rule, it is a word that boys and men use to refer to themselves. Its elements: _person_ . . . _husbands_ . . . _in a row upside down_.;1) [[snallygaster](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snallygaster)] 13-5-2008(145): Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig **me** thod, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it's the kanji for "boku." Males usually use either "boku" or "ore" (instead of "watashi") to refer themselves. "Boku" is slightly boyish and soft, "ore" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use "ore" – but when he's one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to "boku" when he pleads "come on baby, it's **ME**!".;2) [[johnskb](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnskb)] 21-5-2006(112): Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s **ME** , Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”.
多;many;" **Many** _moons_ ago, " begins much of Amerindian folklore - a colorful way of saying "Once upon a time" and a great deal of help for remembering this kanji. Here we have two _moons_  (three of them would take us back to the beginning of time, which is further than we want to go), lacking the final stroke because they are partially hidden behind the clouds of time.;1) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 13-2-2008(105): _Two evenings_ too **many**!;2) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 17-3-2006(46): This reminds me of a childish pseudo-confucion rhyme: "He who eats **many** prunes sits on toilet **many** _moons_ ".
声;voice;The _samurai_ at the top is familiar enough. The combination beneath, which looks like a _flag_ with a line running through it, is not. Try to devise some way to take note of it, and pay attention to the writing.;1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 17-7-2007(256): When an enemy's _flag_ is raised, a true _samurai_ can _split_ it in half with just his **voice**.;2) [[bananarama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bananarama)] 2-3-2008(65): Having lost his **voice** , the samurai comunicated to his troops with a striped flag.
現;present;Do not think of a "gift" here, but of the **present** moment, as distinct from the future and the past. The kanji gives us a _ball_ in which we see the **present**  \- obviously a crystal _ball_ that enables us to _see_ things going on at the **present** in faraway places.;1) [[mimiko](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mimiko)] 20-8-2007(176): _The KING_ … can _SEE_ clearly the **PRESENT** state of affairs in the land. (maybe he hees them in the crystal ball on the left?).;2) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 4-1-2008(67): Hey, I want my money back! This crystal _ball_ is out of order, I can _see_ the **present** instead of the future!
平;even;This character is easiest remembered as a pictograph of a water lily floating on the surface of the water, which gives it its meaning of **even**. The fourth stroke represents the calm, smooth surface of a pond, and the final stroke the long stem of the plant reaching underwater.;1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 15-10-2006(106): There's an **even** covering of _water lilies_ on the pond at 金閣寺 （きんかくじ） the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto.;2) [[stshores24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stshores24)] 7-9-2008(50): **Even** if Heisig showed me in person, I still wouldn't believe that this is a _water lily_. I don't get it.
葉;leaf;Three elements are given here: _flower_ . . . _generation_ . . . _tree_. The first and last seem logical enough, since it is the **leaf** that feeds the _flowers_ on a _tree_. The element for _generation_ interposed between the two suggests that the movement of a _tree_ from one _generation_ to the next is like its  "turning over a new **leaf**. ";1) [[nolusu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nolusu)] 13-7-2007(246): On top of the **leaves** a _flower_ appears, promising new _generations_ for the old _tree_ below.;2) [[shimouma](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/shimouma)] 29-3-2008(120): The flower generation spent far too much time up trees trying to smoke leaves.
全;whole;**Wholeness** suggests physical and spiritual health,  "having your act together." The kanji-image for **wholeness** depicts being  " _king_ under your own _umbrella_ ," that is, giving order to your own life.
