I know it sounds terribly abstract, but what could be more abstract than the word **whole**?;1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 18-10-2007(168): The fat _king_ hogs the **whole** space under his _umbrella_. (tweaked version of radical tyro's story. "fat" makes a more vivid image for me.).;2) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 20-12-2005(121): The _king_ takes up the **whole** space under his _umbrella_.
足;leg;_Mouth_ . . . _mending_. Note that the last stroke of _mouth_ and the first of _mending_ overlap.;1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 2-6-2007(218): Captain Ahab lost his **leg** to the great white whale's _mouth_ and had to _mend_ it with a peg **leg**.;2) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 18-1-2008(86): I'll use my _mouth_ to _mend_ your **leg** , I'll kiss it all better :).
切;cut;To the right we see the _dagger_ and next to it the number _seven_ whose primitive meaning we decided would be _diced_ (Frame 7). It is hard to think of **cutting** anything with a knife without imagining one of those skillful Japanese chefs. Only let us say that he has had too much to drink at a party, grabs a _dagger_ lying on the mantelpiece and starts _dicing_ up everything insight, starting with the hors d'oeuvres and going on to the furniture and the carpets....;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 23-7-2007(260): The seven samurai used their swords to **cut** their opponents.;2) [[phauna](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/phauna)] 6-1-2008(83): Seven swords **cut** better than one.
金;gold;If this were not one of the most common characters you will ever have to write, I would apologize for having to give the explanation that follows. Anyway, we want to depict bars of **gold** bullion with an _umbrella_ overhead to shade them from the heat (and perhaps to hide them as well). The bullion is made by melting down all the _scepters_ of the kingdom, _drop_ by _drop_ , and shaping them into bars.;1) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 22-10-2007(173): The fat _king_ taking up the _whole_ space under the _umbrella_ actually isn't fat - he just has two big **gold** bars hidden under his clothes.;2) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 31-1-2008(39): Under the _umbrella's_ shade, the king sang, " _Drop_ it to the left, _drop_ it to the right, give me all the **GOLD** in sight!".
近;near;_Ax_ . . . _road_. Be careful not to confuse with _draw near_ (Frame 204) or _bystander_ (Frame 1090).;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 30-12-2006(261): The end is **near**. The _axe_ -murderer is waiting for you on the _road_ …;2) [[zenkun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zenkun)] 13-3-2006(98): An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long _road_. To make A and B **near** , take an _ax_ , cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done.
色;color;Bound up . . . mosaic.;1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 17-11-2006(213): _Bound up_ in the _Rubik's cube_ are the 6 different **colours**.;2) [[Haych](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Haych)] 22-11-2008(54): Ever look closely at _mosaic_ s? They contain a bunch of images _bound up_ into a larger one. It seems amazing until you realize that the only quality of the smaller images that really matters is their **colour**.
発;discharge;This key word refers to the **discharging** of guns, trains, people, and even words. The elements: _teepee_ . . . _two_ . . . _human legs_. Contrast the writing with frame 63.;1) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 13-4-2008(207): I spent some time in her TEEPEE…just the TWO of us…but I looked between her HUMAN LEGS and I saw a nasty **DISCHARGE** …so I made my 出発 rather hastily.;2) [[nest0r](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/nest0r)] 25-4-2008(101): _Two pairs of human legs_ poking out of a _teepee_ : you know there'll be a **discharge** soon, be it sexual, violent (husband returns home with a weapon), or dishonourable (soldier caught molesting a native), or perhaps all of the above.
母;mama;Look closely at this kanji and you will find the outline of the kanji for _woman_ in it, the second stroke of which has been expanded to make space for the two breasts that make her a **mama**. Likening this sound to a baby nursing at its mother's breast has afforded some scholars of comparative linguistics a way to explain the presence of the same word across a wide range of language groups.;1) [[mr_hans_moleman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mr_hans_moleman)] 5-7-2007(76): The two breasts of a momma who breastfeeds.;2) [[gaijinda](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gaijinda)] 14-10-2007(34): This **mama** had twins, one _mouth_ for each _nipple_.
高;tall;Recalling an image from frame 195, first see the _mouth_ under the extraterrestrial's glass _hood_ , and then the _mouth_ under the _top hat_ of one of his mates who has tried on the strange earthling's headgear only to find that it makes him look much, much **taller** than everyone else.;1) [[Danieru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Danieru)] 30-11-2007(149): Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and _top hat_ , trying to look **TALL**. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.;2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 13-6-2008(82): Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a **TALL** hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).
以;by means of;Picture a _person_ dragging a _plow_ behind, and the _drop of_ sweat which falls from his brow as he does his work. Think of him (or her, for that matter) making a living  " **by means of** the sweat of their brows. ";1) [[Immacolata](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Immacolata)] 3-11-2005(188): A man earns his living **by means of** the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age "ard" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox.;2) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 23-1-2008(42): Mr T now makes a living **by means of** a plow/hoe and the sweat he puts into it.
用;utilize;_Meat_ . . . _walking stick_. Be sure to keep this key word distinct from that for _use_ (Frame 1065). The stroke order is exactly as you would expect it from the order of the primitive elements as given.;1) [[decamer0n](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/decamer0n)] 7-5-2007(141): To tenderize _meat_ in an emergency wilderness situation, just **utilize** your _walking stick_!;2) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 20-12-2007(115): I'll confuse this with [use](../v4/990.html) (#990 使), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, "utilize" has an artificial, business-speak connotation, you only **utilize** "utilize" when you're trying to puff up what you're saying and sound important. So: "BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, **utilizing** the our latest _Flesh_ Grip(tm) technology!" I'm seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of _flesh_ , a short _shaft_ , and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it.
死;death;_Bones_ . . . _spoon_. Note how the first stroke is extended to the right, forming a sort of  "roof" overhead.;1) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 3-11-2005(252): Ok, this is where knowing some Eastern culture comes in handy! In Japanese society, when someone dies they creamate the body and pick out the remaining bones with special chopsticks. In this case, they're out of chopsticks so they decide to use (gasp!) a spoon instead.;2) [[pacersfan218](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pacersfan218)] 1-9-2007(108): Imagine the grim reaper (the bringer of **death** ), carrying a _spoon_ made of human _bones_ instead of a scythe.
八;eight;Just as the Arabic numeral "8" is composed of a small circle followed by a larger one, so the kanji for **eight** is composed of a short line followed by a longer line, slanting towards it but not touching it. And just as the  "lazy 8" is the mathematical symbol for "infinity," so the expanse opened up below these two strokes is associated by the Japanese with the sense of an infinite expanse or something "all-encompassing.";1) [[clemk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/clemk)] 18-6-2006(120): "Hachi" (eight) begins with the sound of the **katakana "ha"** , and it's approximately the same character.;2) [[Rose_Arteth](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rose_Arteth)] 17-8-2007(65): The valcano hasn't erupted for 8 years.
得;gain;Column . . . nightbreak . . . glue.;1) [[Spidercat](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Spidercat)] 21-1-2008(211): To **gain** more knowledge of what's goin on in the world I'm reading _column_ after _column_ of articles in the newspapers, and it takes so much time I'm _glued_ to it till _nightbreak_.;2) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 20-9-2008(106): Imagine fat people……they avoid _going_ outside to exercise and stay _glued_ to their TV set until _nightbreak_ ….so of course they **gain** weight.
頭;head;Here we meet at last the full kanji on which the primitive for **head** is based. The elements: _table_ . . . _head_.;1) [[blackstockc](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/blackstockc)] 17-2-2008(215): The **head** of the family sits at the **head** of the _table_.;2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 25-10-2008(87): _Mr. Bean_ has a funny **_head_**.
次;next;This key word connotes the " **next** in line " of a succession of people or things. Let there be a _lack_ of _ice_ on the hottest day of summer, and you stand impatiently in line waiting for the distributor to call out  " **Next**! ";1) [[g33kette](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/g33kette)] 4-3-2008(121): Is this store _lack_ ing _ice_? Let's try the **next** one, then.;2) [[Lozza](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Lozza)] 18-7-2008(89): A rapper called "Ice" went for auditions but was told he lacked talent. **Next** …
天;heavens;This character is meant to be a pictograph of a great man, said to represent the Lord of the **Heavens**. (You may, of course, use the elements _ceiling_ and _St. Bernard_ instead.);1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 14-1-2006(123): If you think of the sky as a _ceiling_ above our heads, here you have the **heavens** as the _largest ceiling_ you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the _ceiling_ primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.;2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 26-10-2006(48): The _ceiling_ that all _large dogs_ aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, _All Dogs Go to Heaven_.
夫;husband;The kanji for _a_ **husband** or  "head of the family" is based on the kanji for _large_ and an extra line near the top for the  "head." Recall the kanji for _heavens_  already learned back in frame 457, and be sure to keep your story for this kanji different.;1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 15-10-2006(233): Even though it is argued size is not important, I'm sure most women would like their **husband** to have a _big one_.;2) [[daredawg3583](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/daredawg3583)] 25-2-2007(72): Homer Simpson, as a primitive.
真;true;Here again we meet the composite element, _eye of the needle_ , which here combines with _tool_ to give us a measure of what is **true** and what is not.;1) [[pmbeddall](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pmbeddall)] 2-10-2007(262): A compass is a _tool_ with a _needle_ on top that points to **true** north.;2) [[indigo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/indigo)] 5-12-2007(159): _Ten_ _tools_ are all a **true** craftsman needs.
父;father;The kindness and hard work of the ideal **father** is seen in this abbreviation of the _taskmaster_ that leaves off his rod or whip (the first stroke) and replaces it with the sweat of the **father's** brow (the two _drops_ at the top).;1) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 2-2-2008(214): Luke, I am your **father**. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords).;2) [[sleepyday](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sleepyday)] 26-10-2008(59): Not to confuse anyone, but I think if you put your mind to it, you can see the image of a **father** here. The first two strokes take on the form of his eye brows, and the third and fourth stroke make up the nose and mustache.
親;parent;Red pepper . . . see.;1) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 13-3-2007(321): I remember this one the way the Japanese do: a **parent** _standing_ on top of a _tree_ _watching_ what his or her kid is doing.;2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 14-12-2006(80): A wise **parent** lets their kids learn. A kid wants to try to eat the _red pepper plant_ , the wise **parent** says "Try it and _see_ for yourself".
帰;homecoming;_Spear_ . . . _broom_ . . . _apron_. The character for _lady_ (Frame 1234) shares the same right side as this character, which does not bode for a very happy **homecoming**.;1) [[mspertus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mspertus)] 12-10-2007(227): A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her _spear_ to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a _broom_ and an _apron_. “Boy, this is some kind of **HOMECOMING** ,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb).;2) [[Viking101](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Viking101)] 4-1-2010(48): Our high school theme was tradition. They gave the **homecoming** king a _spear_ and the **homecoming** queen a _broom_ and _apron_.
対;vis-à-vis;Plaid . . . glue.;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 11-9-2007(205): When sitting **vis-a-vis** , _Scots_ will _glue_ their _kilt_ down to avoid embaressment.;2) [[laxxy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/laxxy)] 8-10-2006(81): This is a character that is used in Japanese for "vs." (as in, "Alien vs. Predator").
美;beauty;Try to think of what the Chinese were on to when they associated the idea of **beauty** with a _large sheep_.;1) [[Howdoken](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Howdoken)] 4-1-2008(163): I guess this kanji proves it's not just the Welsh whose idea of **beauty** is a _large_ _sheep_.;2) [[narafan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/narafan)] 25-7-2007(75): A _Sheep_ on top of a _dog_ is NOT a **beautiful** thing.
六;six;The primitives here are _top hat_ and _animal legs_. Once again, we glide over them until later.;1) [[Andre_Breton](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Andre_Breton)] 5-12-2007(127): Indicating 6 parts of the human body: head, body, 2 arms, 2 legs.;2) [[Jeromin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Jeromin)] 22-12-2008(69): The Devil, always a gentleman, wears a top hat, but his goat legs, betray the Beast. 666 is his number.
引;pull;Bow . . . walking stick.;1) [[radical_tyro](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/radical_tyro)] 24-6-2007(188): Put a _walking stick_ in the _bow_ and **pull** it back, ready to fire at the geezer.;2) [[eugs51](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/eugs51)] 2-11-2007(175): This is actually a bow and an arrow. (Real origin of this kanji). **Pull** and release to fire!
野;plains;This character refers to rustic life and rustic fields primarily, and from there gets derived meanings. Its elements: _computer_. . _beforehand_.;1) [[BlackMarsh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/BlackMarsh)] 20-1-2006(240): These days we all work in front of computers. Beforehand we all worked out in the fields, in the **plains**.;2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 25-2-2007(70): The **plains** are a challenging place to get any work done. Be sure you recharge your _computer's_ battery _beforehand_ , or you won't get anything done.
笑;laugh;Bamboo . . . heavens.;1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 30-1-2007(304): When the people tried to build a tower of _bamboo_ to reach the _heavens_ , the gods just **laughed** and **laughed**.;2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 7-5-2009(101): Tip: 天 and 夭 ( _heavens_ and _sapling_ ) are different, but RTK confuses them sometimes. The latter appears in numbers 634, 938, 2078, 2079, 2080, and all characters containing _angel_ 喬 (429, 430, 1221, 2104, 2120, 2369). Story: The fully-grown _bamboo_ trees are **laugh** ing at the little _sapling_.
音;sound;The kanji for **sound** depicts something _standing_ in the air over a _tongue wagging in a mouth_ , much the same as a **sound** does for the briefest of moments before disappearing.;1) [[Aploosh](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Aploosh)] 23-8-2007(201): If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you'd be making **sound**.;2) [[HMiettinen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/HMiettinen)] 21-10-2007(75): The _tongue wagging in a mouth_ produces a very high-pitched **sound** , breaking a nearby _vase_.
表;surface;_Grow up_ . . . _rags_. This character represents the  "outside" of a garment, just as the kanji for _back_ (Frame 426) depicted the  "inside" or lining.;1) [[ergerg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ergerg)] 17-7-2006(239): When I was GROWING UP, the **SURFACE** of my SCARF was always covered with snot from blowing my nose on it.;2) [[Green_Airplane](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Green_Airplane)] 6-8-2008(97): As girls _grow up_ , something slowly **surfaces** from under their _scarf_.
等;etc.;Bamboo . . . Buddhist temple.;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 19-2-2007(452): The _Bamboo Buddhist Temple_ has bamboo buddhas, bamboo buildings, bamboo benches, bamboo beds, bamboo bowls, **etc.** **etc.** **etc.**;2) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 28-11-2007(138): "So what'd you see in Japan?" - " _Bamboo_ , _temples_ … **etc.** ".
情;feelings;_State of mind_ . . . _blue_. Do not confuse with _emotion_ (Frame 662).;1) [[joesan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joesan)] 19-11-2007(174): _Data_ is **feeling** _blue_ about not having any **feelings** … hey, wait a minute.;2) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 15-11-2006(150): Feeling blue is a state of mind where you're dominated by your **feelings**.
歩;walk;_Footprints_ that follow one another a _few_ at a time indicate **walking**.;1) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 24-1-2006(188): When **walk** ing your pet, you must _stop_ a _few_ times along the way when nature calls.;2) [[Delina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Delina)] 28-2-2008(79): When you learn to **walk** , you take your _steps_ a _few_ at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every _few_ _steps_ but keeps getting up to try again.
馬;horse;Let the extra vertical stroke in the _mane_ combine with the first vertical stroke to give an image of the **horse's** long neck. The only odd thing is the _tail feathers_ at the end, but that should present a good image to remember the character by. The fact that the last stroke of _mane_ and the first of _tail feathers_ coincide should no longer surprise you.;1) [[raulir](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raulir)] 5-1-2007(124): Turkey with the drops at the top removed and tail feathers added (this matches stroke order and there are the tail feathers already, why not have the whole bird). If you take the two drops of 隹 as wings, then **horse** s are like turkeys, but have no wings and have more prominent tail "feathers". Both are actually supposed to be pictographs, though.;2) [[NeoGlitch](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NeoGlitch)] 18-1-2012(42): **FINALLY!! Geeeeeeeeeez!!!**.
形;shape;Two hands . . . shape.;1) [[akrodha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/akrodha)] 31-5-2007(147): Everyone in the kindergarten came up with fun and interesting **shape** s made out of _Play-Doh_ , except for the kid with the amputated arm. Seems like you _really need both hands_.;2) [[Thora](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thora)] 19-3-2008(78): With your _two hands_ , outline the _shape_ of a curvaceous woman. Is that a universally understood gesture? [Careful: [mould](../v4/680.html) (#680 型) which has two hands and soil/clay].
太;plump;" **Plump** " is one of those delightful English words that almost sound like their meaning. No sooner do you hear it than you think of a round and ample- bodied person falling into a sofa like a _large drop_ of oil plopping into a fishbowl - kerrrr- **plump**!;1) [[lilpea](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lilpea)] 3-8-2007(152): A _large_ person with a big _drop_ of sweat dripping off of him because he is so **plump**.;2) [[chamcham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/chamcham)] 27-2-2006(80): Fat("plump") men always have small penises…..the kanji is a combination of "large" with a drop(representing the small penis between his legs).
川;stream;We have taken the image of a river **stream** over into English to describe things that fall down in straight lines, or ripple along in lines. All of this is more than evident in the kanji given here, a pictograph of a **stream**.;1) [[ceeeps](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ceeeps)] 2-9-2007(86): So as not to confuse this with [river](../v4/146.html) (#146 河) think of **stream** ers falling down.;2) [[dogen2](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dogen2)] 17-3-2007(63): There are _three_ default I/O **Streams** in UNIX, stdin, stdout, and stderr.
落;fall;When _water_ **falls** , it splats and splashes, when _flower_ petals **fall** , they float gently in the breeze. To _each_ thing its own way of **falling**.;1) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 18-9-2007(184): Water each flower or the petals will wither and **fall**.;2) [[pm215](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/pm215)] 15-2-2008(120): [It's been suggested on the forum (<http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079>) that _flower_ across the full width of the kanji and _water_ on the left below it should have its own keyword, _seaweed_ is a popular choice. See also [dilute](../v4/227.html) (#227 薄), [clan](../v4/1912.html) (#1912 藩), [seaweed](../v4/2035.html) (#2035 藻). This story is for the benefit of those using that idea.] Picture a group of Japanese skydivers **fall** ing through the sky – suddenly _each_ one opens, instead of a parachute, an enormous sheet of nori _seaweed_ to carry them safely down.

七;seven;Note that the first stroke "cuts" through the second. This distinguishes **seven** from the character for _spoon_  (Frame 476), in which the horizontal stroke stops short.;1) [[munia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/munia)] 15-11-2005(243): This kanji is our good old **seven** , turned upside down.;2) [[Angrybeez](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Angrybeez)] 10-6-2008(68): I wrote it upside down so I crossed it out.
有;possess;The picture here is of someone with a slab of _meat_ dangling _by the side_ , perhaps from a belt or rope tied around the waist. Think of it as an evil spirit in **possession** of one's soul, who can be exorcized only by allowing fresh _meat_ to hang _by one's side_ until it begins to putrefy and stink so bad that the demon departs. Take careful note of the stroke order.;1) [[ruisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ruisu)] 7-9-2007(221): **Possess** ed by the Earth's gravity, the moon stays by its side.;2) [[notgoing2argue](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/notgoing2argue)] 12-3-2007(47): By my side I **POSSESS** a _moon of flesh_ , better known as your big ass!

Imagine _Tom Cruise_ outside in the final scene, stabbing his knife into his stomach, while _Mr T_ looks patiently on. "I pity da foo….no, really.".

直;straightaway;Begin with the top two primitives, _needle_ and _eye_. Together they represent the _eye of a needle_. Below them is a _fishhook_ that has been **straightened out** and its barb removed so that it can pass through the _eye of the needle_.;1) [[moojitsu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/moojitsu)] 5-10-2006(333): If you get a needle in your eye that is hooked in there, get to a hospital **straightaway**.;2) [[zdude255](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zdude255)] 20-3-2008(126): I caught a freaky creature with ten eyes on my fish hook, so I threw it back **straightaway**.
達;accomplished;The key word is meant to connote someone "skilled" at something. On the _road_ we find _soil_ OVER _a sheep_. You may have to work with this one a while longer.;1) [[Transtic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Transtic)] 30-12-2007(202): Dolly (the first cloned **sheep** ever) grow tired of being a celebrity and escaped from the labs by digging a tunnel. She turned out to be an **ACCOMPLISHED** escapist, as she managed to dig a **road** under the **soil**. **/** Imagine Dolly performing a escape, like those movies where the main character has to escape from jail.;2) [[erlog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/erlog)] 20-3-2007(87): The dirty sheep had come far down this road and had **accomplished** many things.

Evaporation anyone?
活;lively;When we speak of a **lively** personality or a **lively** party, we immediately think of a lot of chatter. This kanji depicts the idea of **lively** by having _tongues_ babble and splash around like flowing _water_.;1) [[etpan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/etpan)] 18-5-2008(201): I'm sure I can get her pretty **lively** and _wet_ using my _tongue_.;2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 18-8-2007(176): Conversations can become more **lively** after everyone has had a few drinks. 込;crowded;Enter . . . road.;1) [[skinnyneo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/skinnyneo)] 11-10-2007(167): During a traffic jam it is impossible to get your car to _enter_ the _roadway_ as it is **crowded** with cars. 村;town;The character for _village_ was associated with _rice fields_ (Frame 96). That for **town** , a step up on the evolutionary path to cities, shows a circle of _trees glued together_ to measure off the confines of a **town**.;1) [[zhangqiezi](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/zhangqiezi)] 29-5-2008(230): If you've ever played an old 8 bit or 16 bit RPG, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy or Inindou, you'll remember that every _town_ was all bordered off by a line of _trees_ with no space in between to get out through. At it's core, a **town** is just a bunch of _wood_ _glued_ together. Edit - Stop starring this piece of crap story! xD.
語;word;Whereas the character for _say_ focused on the actual talking, that for **words** stresses the fact that although it is _I_ who _say_ them, the **words** of a language are not my own. You can see the clear distinction between _I_ and **words** just by looking at the kanji.;1) [[rosie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rosie)] 28-7-2008(226): The simplest **word** to _say_ is _I_.;2) [[uchifly](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/uchifly)] 15-12-2009(43): Jesus said, "I am the **WORD**.".
教;teach;Filial piety . . . taskmaster.;1) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 16-5-2007(280): In early Japan, _filial piety_ was the cornerstone of education, and harsh _taskmasters_ were employed to **teach** it.;2) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 24-12-2005(74): You could say that the _taskmistress_ is **teach** ing you _filial piety_ when she whips you and asks, "Who's your daddy?!".

社;company;_Altar_ . . . _soil_. The **company** referred to here is that of the modern business world.;1) [[mfistik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mfistik)] 6-8-2007(304): When you enter a Japanese **company** it's like you join a cult… your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on.;2) [[Delina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Delina)] 13-6-2008(54): Some Japanese **companies** , including Toyota, have a Shinto _shrine_ on their _grounds_ to bring luck and prosperity to the **company** and its employees.
門;gates;The pictograph of two swinging **gates** is so clear in this kanji that only its stroke order needs to be memorized. In case you should have any trouble, though, you might doodle with the shapes on a piece of paper, taking care to note the difference in the stroke order of the two facing doors. The **gates** usually serve as an enclosure, and are written BEFORE whatever it is they enclose.;1) [[dukelexon](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dukelexon)] 16-1-2008(175): Heisig's stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful – first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the "sun" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you'll get the stroke order exactly correct.;2) [[scottamus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/scottamus)] 4-9-2006(56): The **gates** to Hell. guarded by Cerebus or … Bill **Gates**?
士;gentleman;The shape of this kanji, slightly differing from that for _soil_ by virtue of its shorter final stroke, hints at a broad-shouldered, slender-waisted warrior standing at attention. When feudalism collapsed, these warriors became Japan's **gentlemen**.;1) [[gsantise](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/gsantise)] 27-8-2007(132): What a handsome **gentleman**. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He's like a modern samurai!;2) [[mightymiff](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mightymiff)] 17-7-2009(49): A **gentleman** has broad shoulders and doesn't soil himself.
別;separate;In the Old East, the samurai and his _saber_ were never **separated**. They were constant companions, like the cowboy of the Old West and his six-shooter. This character depicts what must have been the height of **separation** -anxiety for a samurai: to be _bound up with a rope_ and unable to get at his _saber_ leaning only a few feet away from him. Look at that _mouth_ bellowing out for shame and sorrow! Note the order in which the element for _tied up_ is written - just as it had been with the character for _ten thousand_.;1) [[leviathan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/leviathan)] 20-3-2006(154): I don't know about you but to me this seems like someone's head is about to be **separate** d from his body. You can see he's kneeling and his mouth is wide open gasping for the last breath he will ever take.;2) [[thatkidpercy](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thatkidpercy)] 16-11-2007(119): A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their _mouths bound up_ to keep them quiet) in a **separate** room from his _sabers_. Putting them together would be a silly mistake.
光;ray;There are really only 2 primitives here, _little_ and _human legs_. The 4th stroke that separates them is added for reasons of aesthetics. (If that doesn't make sense, try writing the kanji without it and see how ugly the results look, even to your beginner's eye.) Now if you have wondered what those little particles of  "dust" are that dance around in the light- **rays** that come through the window and fall on your desk, try imagining them as _little_ and disembodied _human legs_ , and you should have no trouble with this character.;1) [[guidedog](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/guidedog)] 9-2-2007(132): A **ray** of light is not a wave but made of _little_ photons with _human legs_.;2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 27-9-2007(86): The **ray** from Honey I Shrunk the Kids made people _little_ \- ha! look at them run around on their tiny _legs_!
好;fond;The phrase "to be **fond** of someone " has a natural gentleness about it, and lends a tenderness to the sense of touching by giving us the related term "to **fondle**. " The character likens it to a _woman_ **fondling** her _child_.;1) [[snozle](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/snozle)] 8-10-2006(182): A _woman_ is **fond** of her _child_.;2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 23-7-2007(13): Women are **fond** of children.

結;tie;Thread . . . aerosol can.;1) [[Nukemarine](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nukemarine)] 25-1-2008(168): Ok, here, you have to think of the phrase "TIE the knot" , which means a wedding (this kanji is used in the marriage compound 結婚 けっこん ). 処;dispose;Both the stretching out of the _walking legs_ and the little bit of _wind_ tucked in on the right suggest using one's legs to kick something out of the way, or **dispose** of it.;1) [[thegeezer3](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/thegeezer3)] 16-5-2007(278): The best way to **dispose** of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.;2) [[anthropic](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/anthropic)] 12-7-2008(146): To **dispose** of rubbish you should _walk_ it to the bin not throw it to the _wind_.
原;meadow;Though the kanji is broad enough to embrace both meanings, the **meadow** you should imagine here is not a flatland plain but a mountain **meadow** in the Austrian Alps. (Perhaps the opening scene of  "The Sound of Music" will help.) Simply think of little _springs_ bubbling up across the **meadow** to form a sort of path that leads you right to the brink of a precipitous _cliff_. Now if you can see Schwester Maria skipping along merrily, dodging in and out of the _springs_ , and then falling headlong over the _cliff_ , you have a ridiculous story that should help fix this kanji in memory.;1) [[brian44](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/brian44)] 28-8-2007(148): Follow the _springs_ down the _cliff_ and you will find a nice **meadow**.;2) [[LeoOra](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/LeoOra)] 7-2-2008(73): Sorry about this, but Heisig was stupid calling this kanji **meadow** , used in composite words the most common meaning is **ORIGIN** … To remember just think that life may have begun in _pound_ s or _spring_ s in a land with many _cliff_ s … Just to answer correctly the review lessons think of **meadow** as the _origin_ of a huge forest.
説;explanation;Not inappropriately, this character likens an  **explanation** to the _devil's_ own _words_.;1) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 5-2-2008(133): The _words_ of a _horny teenager_ typically fall into one of two categories: either **rumors** or **explanation** s.;2) [[SammyB](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/SammyB)] 11-6-2008(97): The _words_ of the _devil_ incite **rumours** and false **explanations**.
車;car;You may keep the whole range of connotations for this keyword, **car** , provided it does not interfere with the pictograph. Look for the front and back wheels (the first and last horizontal strokes) and the seat in the carriage in the middle. As an exercise, try to isolate the primitives on your own and make a story out of them.;1) [[Twentytw0](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Twentytw0)] 19-7-2007(151): My **car** is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.;2) [[saranich](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/saranich)] 20-1-2006(17): Actually, this is a 10x10 **car** that can get you through a rice field.
起;rouse;Run . . . snake.;1) [[onsen_monkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/onsen_monkey)] 26-9-2006(181): Be careful when you're RUNNING through the jungle, because you might step on and **ROUSE** a sleeping SNAKE. Then you'll have to RUN like hell before it bites you!;2) [[mfistik](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mfistik)] 16-10-2007(97): Nothing will **rouse** you quite as much as finding a snake in your bed. You will run away like you've never run before!
字;character;Here is the character for **character** itself. Not just kanji, but any written **character** from hieroglyphs to Sanskrit to our own Roman alphabet. It shows us simply a _child_ in a _house_. But let us take advantage of the double-meaning of the key word to note that just as a _child_ born to a Japanese _house_ is given **characters** for its name, so it is also stamped with the **character** of those who raise it from infancy on.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 30-7-2007(110): CHILDren learn Kanji **character** s underneath a HOUSE.;2) [[komodo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/komodo)] 22-6-2008(82): "Why do I have to wear this roof on my head all the time father?" "Shut up! It builds **character**!".
流;current;_Water_ . . . _infant_ . . . _flood_. Be sure to distinguish the two water primitives from one another in making your story.;1) [[Dragg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Dragg)] 21-11-2007(254): INFANT Moses placed in the WATER and sent down the **current** of the STREAM.;2) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 10-10-2005(57): A water-breathing infant (genetically modified?) is caught in a flood, and drifts with the **current** , apparently enjoying himself in the process.
吉;good luck;Here we see a _samurai_ standing on a street with an open _mouth_ , which people walk up to and look down deep inside of for **good luck**.;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 6-2-2007(310): The _samurai_ 's wife gives him a (uhum) before battle for **good luck**.;2) [[jonobugs](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jonobugs)] 27-5-2008(117): A true samurai gentleman will always mouth, " **Good luck** " to his opponents before a match.
点;spot;If you look into the flickering of a _fire_ for a long time and then turn aside, you will see **spots** before your eyes. Although nobody ever thought of such a thing before - as least as far as know, they didn't - imagine using those **spots** as a technique for _fortune-telling_. The old witch sits before her _cauldron_ and watches the **spots** that show up when she turns to look at you, and from that _tells your fortune_. Think of it as a kind of **spot** -check on your future.;1) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 27-7-2007(226): The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the **spot** because she was accused of being a witch.;2) [[etpan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/etpan)] 12-6-2008(138): You have to stimulate the G-spot with your _magic wand_ in order to get her on _fire_. Or you can juste use your _mouth_ …
他;other;Person . . . scorpion.;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 7-3-2007(161): It's one or the **other** : fight _Mr. T_ , or be thrown into the _scorpion_ pit.;2) [[astridtops](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astridtops)] 25-7-2006(67): Old latin saying: homo hominis scorpio ( _people_ are _scorpions_ to **other** _people_ ).
想;concept;To distinguish this kanji from that of the previous frame, focus on the sense of the "con-" in the word " **concept**. " Its elements are: _inter-_ . . . _heart_.;1) [[cheechuan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cheechuan)] 29-11-2007(364): The **concept** of love is basically two _hearts_ _inter_ -acting as one.;2) [[Francois](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Francois)] 16-4-2008(61): _''Inter-heart''_ is a new therapy _CONCEPT_ that helps macho guys share their feelings with each other.
校;exam;Tree . . . mingle.;1) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 28-6-2012(209): The schools that accepted them were posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around trying to find their names. (コオ）.;2) [[JetSetArnett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/JetSetArnett)] 12-3-2009(136): Note: this Kanji does _not_ mean **exam**. It means school. I find this keyword an choice odd as **school** by itself is not used elsewhere. **Exam** ples: 校長 is principal (lit. school chief), 中学校 is junior high school (lit. middle study/knowledge school).

愛;love;Birdhouse . . . heart . . . walking legs.;1) [[Thunderball](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thunderball)] 5-8-2007(263): If you really **love** someone, you won't keep them in a cage-like _bird house_ relationship, but rather open the door and let their _heart_ _walk_ around freely. Think less about "I" (あい) and more about "we".;2) [[szreter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/szreter)] 17-3-2008(156): The man is about to enter the ' _birdhouse_ ' (brothel) when he remembers his true _love_ at home, and, following his _heart_ , uses his _walking legs_ to go straight home.
百;hundred;The Japanese refer to a person's 99th birthday as a " _white_ year " because _white_ is the kanji you are left with if you subtract _one_ from a **hundred**.;1) [[noushina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/noushina)] 30-12-2006(152): 100 turned sideways. sort of the same as what ashoksaraf said.;2) [[sethimayne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sethimayne)] 22-9-2007(89): That dirty ceiling was painted WHITE a **hundred** times!
我;ego;_Hand_ . . . _fiesta_. Note how the second stroke of the _hand_ is stretched across to double up as the first stroke of the tasseled arrow we use for _fiesta_. Compare to frames 17, 36, and 564.;1) [[GhettoPenguin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/GhettoPenguin)] 14-3-2007(498): Someone with a huge **EGO** is too good for any romantic partner and as such has nothing but personal " _hand_ _fiesta_ s" with himself every night.;2) [[frozach](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/frozach)] 1-8-2007(50): Did you hear about the guy who had such a big **EGO** that he threw a fiesta for his left hand?
化;change;Person . . . spoon.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 30-12-2005(117): Referring to a scene in the movie "The Matrix" where a girl bends a spoon with the power of her mind alone, I imagine _Mister T_ who **change** s a _spoon_ into something else (maybe the waiter forgot to bring knives or forks). Note: as a primitive, it can help to use the image of "spare **change** ", this can help you keep it distinct from other similar kanji such as "shape" or "turn into".;2) [[ezmoreldo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ezmoreldo)] 3-4-2008(95): I just see this one as a pictograph of a person changing position and sitting down.
古;old;The primitive elements that compose this character are _ten_ and _mouth_ , but you may find it easier to remember it as a pictograph of a tombstone with a cross on top. Just think back to one of those graveyards you have visited, or better still, used to play in as a child, with **old** inscriptions on the tombstones. This departure from the primitive elements in favor of a pictograph will take place now and again at these early stages, and almost never after that. So you need not worry about cluttering up your memory with too many character  "drawings.";1) [[Thaliel](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Thaliel)] 8-7-2006(191): Tombstone and cross on an **old** man's grave.;2) [[rajivp](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rajivp)] 31-10-2007(76): You get **OLD** fast if you have ten open mouths to feed.
置;placement;Eye . . . straightaway.;1) [[icamonkey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/icamonkey)] 11-8-2008(287): Working in retail you learn the **placement** of any item should be at _eye_ level so it's seen _straightaway_.;2) [[jimsublimeman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jimsublimeman)] 30-10-2007(188): On the JET Programme, many people have their _eye_ on a **placement** in Tokyo, Osaka or another big city, and write it on their application form. They are usually sent to the countryside _straightaway_.
命;fate;This character connotes life in general, but also the particular life that is **fated** one by virtue of the distinctive character with which one is born. Its elements are: _fit_ . . . _stamp_. The bottom portion of _fit_ is nudged to the left in order to make room for the _stamp_.;1) [[Megaqwerty](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Megaqwerty)] 1-6-2007(240): When you're born, your **fate** is measured, _fitted_ , and _stamped_ onto your soul. Good luck defying it.;2) [[tharvey](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/tharvey)] 19-7-2009(109): It is your **fate** to _meet_ with a _mouth_ , young _postage stamp_.
違;difference;Locket . . . road.;1) [[sweetneet](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sweetneet)] 30-8-2006(221): You lose your precious _locket_ on the _road_ to somewhere. You ask people if they've seen it, but no luck. "Just buy another one," someone says. "I mean, what's the **difference**?" Then of course you say "Well, it makes a huge **difference**!! Since it has sentimental value, I don't want a different one! " Then of course they understand.;2) [[romanrozhok](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/romanrozhok)] 17-2-2008(68): You loose your LOCKET on the ROAD and report it to the 交番 . They find one, and show it to you. 「これですか？」 But it's the wrong one… You say, 「いいえ。。 **違います** 。。」.
如;likeness;Pardon me if I revert to the venerable old Dr. Freud again, but his eye for symbolism is often helpful to appreciate things that more earthy imaginations once accepted more freely but that we have learned to cover over with a veneer of etiquette. For instance, the fact that things like the _mouth_ of a cave served as natural ritual substitutes for the opening through which a _woman_ gives birth. Hence, in order to be reborn as an adult, one may have to pass through the psychological equivalent of the womb, that is, something that bears a **likeness** to the _opening_ of the _woman_ from whom you were born.;1) [[smujohnson](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smujohnson)] 17-7-2008(363): _Women_ share a common **likeness**. Their _mouth_ s are always open, whining about this and that.;2) [[At0m5k](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/At0m5k)] 21-8-2008(133): A _woman_ 's _mouth_ has the **likeness** of a vaccum cleaner, it's noisy and all it's good for is sucking. Do not confuse with [resemblance](../v4/114.html) (#114 肖). **Likeness** is purely conceptual, whereas resemblance refers to actual physical similarities.
朝;morning;On the right we see the _moon_ fading off into the first light of **morning** , and to the left, the _mist_ that falls to give nature a shower to prepare it for the coming heat. If you can think of the _moon_ tilting over to spill _mist_ on your garden, you should have no trouble remembering which of all the elements in this story are to serve as primitives for constructing the character.;1) [[Rinifett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rinifett)] 25-9-2007(186): There is mist as the moon fades away in the **morning**.;2) [[Yasser](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Yasser)] 19-10-2008(96): **Morning** has come "ten" hours "early"!!! The "moon" is still in the sky!
返;return;Anti- . . . road.;1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 7-5-2006(121): Pretty obvious: to **return** is to turn back on the road you're on and go the opposite way.;2) [[etpan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/etpan)] 16-7-2008(98): **Return** here means "return something" rather than "go back". So here it goes, for those of you who are also suffering of the Japanese summer ,-) I ordered an _anti_ mosquito kit, but it was damaged on the _way_ so I had to **return** it.
関;connection;Gates . . . golden calf.;1) [[Rakushun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Rakushun)] 27-12-2007(150): The _golden calf_ is sent to the _gates of Hell_ for it's **connection** to false idols.;2) [[szreter](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/szreter)] 8-7-2008(75): There's a weird **connection** between worshipping the _golden calf_ and visiting the _gates of Hell_.
数;number;Rice . . . woman . . . taskmaster.;1) [[astgtciv](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/astgtciv)] 4-4-2007(264): Young _taskmaster_ is learning **numbers** by watching _women_ haul sacks of _rice_ past him. "One… two… four! No, wrong! Go back, go back!".;2) [[Johnnyltn](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Johnnyltn)] 20-8-2006(79): _Women_ toil in the _rice_ fields carrying heavy sacks of _rice_ to be **number** ed and counted by the _taskmaster_.
氏;family name;Pay close attention to the stroke order of the elements when learning to write this character. The elements: a long _drop_ . . . _fishhook_ . . . a _one_ . . . _fishhook_.;1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 12-11-2007(239): Looks a bit like Ft => **F** amily **t** itle => **Family name**.;2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 19-10-2006(75): The **family name** is important to me! _Drop_ me from a building, torture me with a _fishhook_ , I'm keeping my _one_ **family name**. Hook me with a second _fishhook_ , I refuse to change my **family name**.
石;stone;With a _mouth_ under a _cliff_ , what else could we have here but the entrance to a secret cavern, before which a great **stone** has been rolled so that none may enter. Perhaps it is the hiding place where Ali Baba and his band of thieves have stored their treasures, in which case that magic word known to every school child who ever delighted over the tales of the _Arabian Nights_ should be enough to push the **stone** aside. But take care - the _cliff_ is steep, and one slip will send you tumbling down into the ravine below. This is the one and only time that the second stroke in _cliff_ will reach over to the middle of the horizontal stroke. If you think of the edge jutting outwards (in keeping with the story above), the problem should be taken care of.;1) [[Ninjasha](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ninjasha)] 31-12-2007(142): Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of _cliff_ just in time to evade the huge **STONE** rolling out of the _mouth_ of the cave!;2) [[Nayelianne](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Nayelianne)] 19-9-2008(37): There's a VERY simple way to remember this, in case the _cliff_ thing isn't working for you… Just see it as a **stone** [いし] being _hammered_ by a miner searching for jewel **stone** s [ほう **せき** ] ,).
早;early;This kanji is actually a picture of the first flower of the day, which we shall, in defiance of botanical science, call the _sun_ flower, since it begins with the element for _sun_ and is held upon a stem with leaves (the pictographic representation of the final two strokes). This time, however, we shall ignore the pictograph and imagine _sun_ flowers with _needles_ for stems, which can be plucked and used to darn your socks. The sense of **early** is easily remembered if one thinks of the _sun_ flower as the **early** riser in the garden, because the _sun_ , showing favoritism towards its namesake, shines on it before all the others (see frame 10).;1) [[sutebun](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sutebun)] 2-7-2007(290): The _sun_ up is **early** , well before _ten_.;2) [[Christine_Tham](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Christine_Tham)] 21-7-2007(34): An **early** sun-flower looks like a miniature sun perched on a needlelike stems.
海;sea;Behind _every drop of water_ , a **sea** from which it originated.;1) [[Codexus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Codexus)] 6-12-2007(184): _Every_ drop of _water_ will eventually return to the **sea**.;2) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 9-8-2008(22): As depicted in the classic SF film _Fantastic Voyage_ , every drop of water is a **sea** , if you look close enough. Imagine peering through a microscope at a vast **sea** teeming with microbial life (and perhaps a minaturized submarine). **Note:** Take care not to confuse with [ocean](../v4/549.html) (#549 洋).
常;usual;Outhouse . . . towel.;1) [[Avispa](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Avispa)] 31-8-2007(236): It's **usual** to take your _towel_ with your when you go to the _outhouse_ at the onsen (hot springs bath in Japan) so everybody doesn't see your stuff.;2) [[Asgard](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Asgard)] 2-9-2006(91): In the _outhouse_ toilet you'd **usual** ly hope to find toilet paper to wipe your ass. If it's already gone, which is **usual** ly the case, simply use the _towel_.

九;nine;If you take care to remember the stroke order of this kanji, you will not have trouble later keeping it distinct from the kanji for _power_ (Frame 922).;1) [[joeyjpm](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joeyjpm)] 15-7-2008(161): _Warning - naughty reminder_ A woman in the doggie style position, waiting for my **NINE** inches.;2) [[Gunii](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Gunii)] 12-2-2008(157): Kinda of looks like the kanji of 1 一 with the kanji of 8 八 added. 解;unravel;Angle . . . dagger . . . cow.;1) [[ergerg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ergerg)] 25-11-2006(221): Did you know that you can **unravel** a cow? If you stick the dagger in at exactly the correct angle, the whole cow will just **unravel**.;2) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 20-7-2009(77): **Unravel** the mystery by determining at what ANGLE the SWORD went into the COW.
土;soil;I don't like it any more than you do, but this kanji is not the pictograph it is trumped up to be: a mound of **soil** piled on the ground. All I can recommend is that you memorize it as it is. Anyway, it will be occurring with such frequency that you have almost no chance of forgetting it, even if you try.;1) [[mparrett1](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mparrett1)] 18-6-2006(87): Remembering **soil** is easy. If **soil** is soft, you can take a _walking stick_ and plunge it two* feet into the ground.;2) [[stereovibe](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/stereovibe)] 11-3-2008(32): The grave was marked by a cross sticking out of the **soil**.
戸;door;Ceiling . . . flag.;1) [[matticus](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/matticus)] 10-12-2005(272): Traditional Japanese storefront **door** s have several _flags_ , known as "noren," hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don't usually hang from the _ceiling_.;2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 30-12-2006(37): A Japanese **door** has a noren, a _flag_ hanging from a _rod_. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered **door** ).
東;east;As a "Western" language, English identifies the **east** with the rising _sun_. In more fanciful terms, we see the _sun_ piercing through a _tree_ as it rises in the **east**.;1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 8-1-2006(182): Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.;2) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 7-12-2008(15): Through the _tree_ s, I watch the _sun_ rising from the **east**.
火;fire;Just as sitting before a **fire** enlivens the imagination and lets you see almost anything you want to in the flames, this kanji is so simple it lets you see almost any sort of **fire** you want to see. It no longer makes a good pictograph, but I invite you to take a pencil and paper and play with the form - first writing it as shown below and then adding lines here and there - to see what you can come up with. Everything from matchbooks to cigarette lighters to volcanic eruptions to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah have been found here. No doubt you, too, will find something interesting to bend your memory around these four simple strokes.;1) [[munia](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/munia)] 22-2-2008(57): For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on **fire**!;2) [[raseru](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/raseru)] 16-6-2008(29): A tepee getting shot at by **fire** arrows.
之;of;This character is now used chiefly in proper names, and is best learned as the character closest to the hiragana え, though in fact it has no relation to it.;1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 4-11-2007(292): **Of** all the kanji, this is the only one 之 orro can write.;2) [[Filip](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Filip)] 31-1-2008(110): The Z **of** Zorro (and yes he has a hat).
要;need;Old West . . . woman.;1) [[takoman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/takoman)] 9-6-2008(106): (ヨウ) When Clint **need** s a woman, he likes to be on top.;2) [[mantixen](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mantixen)] 27-9-2008(99): In the _Old West_ , _women_ were **need** ed because nobody knew how to cook or clean.
苦;suffering;The picture of **suffering** we are given here is that of a _flower_ that has grown _old_. When a _flower_ ages, it pales and dries up, and probably even **suffers**. If you think that plants are incapable of such feelings, then ask yourself why so many people believe that talking to their flowers helps them bloom better.;1) [[applesuki](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/applesuki)] 20-9-2006(190): Flowers for the old man **suffering** in the hospital.;2) [[PepeSeco](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/PepeSeco)] 9-5-2007(26): The derivates from opium _poppies_ such as morphine can be used to tame the **suffering** of the _old_.
過;overdo;Jawbone . . . road.;1) [[Talka](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Talka)] 9-9-2007(256): Jaws XII~! Jaws strikes the highway! Man, they're really **overdo** ing it now.;2) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 4-9-2006(180): In 'American History X' Edward Norton's character **overdoes** it when he makes the dude that tried to steal his car lie face down with his _jawbone_ open over the pavement of the _roadway_ and then stamps on the back of his head. My teeth still tingle when I think of that!
定;determine;**Determination** , in the sense of settling on a certain course of action, is likened here to _mending_ one's _house_.;1) [[jrothenberg](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/jrothenberg)] 31-1-2007(231): In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher's HOUSE in various ways.;2) [[khooks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/khooks)] 25-1-2007(88): Prior to buying a home, the _home_ inspector will come into your house and **determine** everything that needs _mending_.
町;village;_Street_ signs standing at the corner of the _rice fields_ depict the **village** limits. (Remember what was said earlier: when used as a primitive, a kanji may either take its primitive meaning or revert to the original meaning of its key word.);1) [[Raichu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Raichu)] 19-11-2006(150): Actually this means **town** , like one that has lots of _streets_ and is surrounded by all the _rice fields_.;2) [[meolox](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/meolox)] 20-8-2008(84): Getting this one confused with Town is easy, so remember it with this rhyme. "Pillage the **village** , for the _rice_ and and the _tea_." the street primitive on the right looks like a 't'.
安;relax;To be told that the place of the _woman_ is in the _house_ may not sit well with modern thought, but like all cultural habits the Chinese characters bear the birthmarks of their age. So indulge yourself in a Norman Rockwell image of **relaxing** after a hard day's work: the scruffy and weary _woman_ of the _house_ slouched asleep in the living room chair, her hair in curlers and a duster lying in her lap.;1) [[elktapestry](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elktapestry)] 27-3-2007(142): It's funny, Hesig gives no Kanji in his book that means cheap/inexpensive… well… if you were wondering what Kanji would carry that meaning, look no further. Sometimes I wonder if Hesig just thinks our little brains would be too easily confused by multiple meanings. Regardless, think of that woman **relax** ing. Cheapest place to do that is in one's own home rather than at some fancy resort, eh? [家で休暇を取るは安いですね。](midori://search?text=家で休暇を取るは安いですね。) .;2) [[enerccio](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/enerccio)] 22-7-2007(83): You can only **relax** , when you have woman under roof to do all chores.
庫;warehouse;Cave . . . car.;1) [[darg_sama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/darg_sama)] 3-11-2005(372): I think of the Batcave. It's a big cave that Batman uses as a **warehouse** to store his car, the Batmobile, and all his cool big-boy toys.;2) [[dizzwave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dizzwave)] 17-6-2008(28): Have you ever worked in a **warehouse**? It's like a giant metal _cave_. Watch out for that _forklift_!
助;help;_Shelf_ . . . _power_. The reason why the _shelf_ appears on the left here is that the right side is the normal position for power, the stronger primitive. Indeed, the only exception in all the kanji is the character for _add_ (Frame 932).;1) [[FudoMyo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/FudoMyo)] 2-5-2007(228): **HELP**! Someone's pinned under this bookshelf and it's gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off!;2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-4-2007(84): Can you **help** me move this _shelf_? I don't have the _muscle_ to do it alone.
頃;about that time;When Uncle Bob starts his comic routine of sticking _spoons_ on his _head_ , you know it is **about that time**  to come up with a reason to excuse yourself.;1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 24-6-2007(164): An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at **about that time** the clock reaches out with a _spoon_ and hits you on the _head_.;2) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 29-11-2008(47): After _spooning_ for hours it's **about that time** he got some _head_. Dayum woman.
民;people;In place of the _drop_ at the start of the character for _family name_ , we have a _mouth_ , which makes you think of the "vox populi.";1) [[burento5](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/burento5)] 22-6-2008(150): How many of you know what "vox populi" means?;2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 12-3-2007(139): All the **people** of the world with all their _family names_ shouting with their big _mouths_.
半;half;Although the writing order is different, one can remember the appearance of this character by seeing it as a _little needle_ \- the kind used for splitting hairs in **half**. (Again, according to rule, _little_ takes a stroke beneath it in order to be placed over an element that has no horizontal line at the top.);1) [[bspeaks](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/bspeaks)] 26-1-2008(361): Imagine karate chopping the number three in **half** with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first "board" breaks.;2) [[lifeflaw](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/lifeflaw)] 15-3-2009(38): I think of this as a pictograph, there are three boards to cut, the first one is already in **half** and there are still two more to go.
又;or again;Like the several abbreviations in Roman script to indicate "and" (+, &, etc.), this short two-stroke kanji is used for the similar meaning of **or again**.;1) [[sindhikara](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/sindhikara)] 1-8-2008(155): This keyword should really be "again" not "or again" Here is some context: think of the phrase "Jya mata" " じゃ又 " which is a farewell similar to "then again". Also "Mata ne" " 又ね " and mata ashita (again tomorrow) " 又明日 "。 Note this kanji is rarely used, most of the time JP people spell it out "mata" except for in the last example: 又明日 .;2) [[smithsonian](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/smithsonian)] 16-4-2007(132): After her boyfriend's _crotch_ has been satisfied, a woman might suggest they cuddle. The boyfriend, on the other hand, might say, " **Or again** , we could fool around . . . ".

They never look up and see the Turkeys that have **gather** ed on top of the trees to hide. Those were some smart turkeys!;2) [[dsamari](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dsamari)] 14-10-2007(110): **Gather** the turkeys for Thanksgiving. **Gather** the trees for Christmas. In that order…
誰;who;Words . . . turkey.;1) [[cameron_en](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cameron_en)] 28-11-2008(87): Do you remember that song where they _say_ " **Who** let the _turkeys_ out!? Gobble.. gobble.. gobble"?;2) [[Ricardo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ricardo)] 5-2-2007(40): [who, someone, somebody] You're alone when, suddenly, you think you hear someone _speak_ ing. " **Who** 's there?", you _say_ , but there is no answer. Then you find out it was only a _turkey_ gobbling. You feel relieved (and ashamed to tell this story). (Based on raulir).
供;submit;**Submit** here is a transitive verb, meaning to offer or present. Its elements: _person_ . . . _strung together_.;1) [[Django](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Django)] 1-10-2007(178): It took over 600 frames for _Mr T_ to [make](../v4/1142.html) (#1142 作), the _Ark_ , but when he was finally done, he cast his saw aside and **submit** ted the _Ark_ to Noah for his approval. "I pity the foo who doesn't climb aboard this ark," said Noah to his friend.;2) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 11-12-2006(69): _Mr. T_ **submits** a resume _together_ with his application. "I pity da foo don't got no resume!" he says.
飛;fly;The two _large hooks_ have little propellers (the two _drops_ on each _hook_ ) attached to them for **flying**. Beneath is the _measuring box_ , which serves as the body of this **flying** contraption. The stroke order will cause some problems, so take care with it.;1) [[CharleyGarrett](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/CharleyGarrett)] 1-1-2007(267): Hooks with small wings attached look like hummingbirds with a long beak. Two hummingbirds are trying to **fly** away with our little measuring box. What do they want it for?;2) [[joxn_costello](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/joxn_costello)] 5-2-2009(36): Two _hummingbirds_ **fly** ing to feed at a _measuring box_ filled with sugar water. **This kanji is famous for having hard-to-remember stroke order.** Try it this way: first a _hummingbird_ **flies** over the _measuring box walls backwards_. But finally the other _hummingbird_ manages to stick its beak right through them.
申;speaketh;The olde English is used here to indicate a humble form of the third person singular of the verb "to speak." It is written by a _tongue wagging in the mouth_ with a _walking stick_ rammed through it and coming out at both ends.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 15-8-2006(181): I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the "s" and **speaketh** like thith becauth they have a _cane_ in their _mouth_.;2) [[mcfate](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mcfate)] 14-2-2008(90): I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 [sayeth](../v4/578.html) (#578 曰). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in "moshi moshi" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say "hello, this is X **speaking**.".

草;grass;Perhaps you know the custom of seeding **grass** randomly or in some particular pattern with the _flower_ called the crocus, which blooms for a few days each year in _early_ spring. As the **grass** begins to turn green again after winter has passed, these tiny _flowers_ dot up here and there. Now just look out your window at a patch of **grass** somewhere and think what a nice idea it would be to have your name spelled out in _flowers_ once as a sort of _early_ harbinger of spring.;1) [[dicedice](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dicedice)] 22-7-2007(266): **Grass** grows in _earlier_ than _flowers_.;2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 1-6-2008(46): This **grass** is very long. The only _flowers_ you can see are _sunflowers_ – the rest are hidden by the **grass**.

機;mechanism;Tree . . . abacus.;1) [[synewave](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/synewave)] 22-10-2006(261): An _abacus_ is a **mechanism** made of _wood_ used to calculate _how many_ 'anythings'.;2) [[rtkrtk](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rtkrtk)] 14-1-2008(75): To avoid confusing with [contraption](../v4/677.html) (#677 械), focus on the "ism" of **mechanism**. For example, fetishism refers to having a fetish, **mechanism** here refers to having a mecha-like property, where mecha is a type of anime robot that can transform itself. Imagine a mecha that can transform itself between two forms: a huge immovable _tree_ (as a form of defense) and a gigantic marching _abacus_ that smashes enemies between its giant beads.

張;lengthen;Bow . . . long.;1) [[rgravina](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/rgravina)] 29-10-2006(238): The longbow is follows the design of a standard _bow_ , only it has been **lengthen** ed.;2) [[johnzep](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/johnzep)] 14-8-2007(71): _Legolas_ recieves spam telling him that his can **lengthen** his "bow"…he smirks…he know's it's already _long_ enough.
余;too much;_Umbrella_ . . . _potato_ . . . _little_. The last stroke of _potato_ and the first of _little_ coincide in this character.;1) [[RoboTact](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/RoboTact)] 11-7-2007(183): You hang an _umbrella_ upside-down on a hook of the **scales** and fill it with _little_ _potatoes_. No luck: it weights **too much**.;2) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 7-3-2008(147): This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means **too little** in negative sentences and **too much** in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol " >" ( **more than** , another meaning!!) as the _umbrella_ component, and using [two](../v4/2.html) (#2 二) and [little](../v4/105.html) (#105 小) for the _potato_ primitive. So, this kanji either means " _two_ much" (more than 2) or " _two little_ ". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!).
皆;all;Think of the housewives in TV commercials " _comparing_ the _whiteness_ " of their laundry across the fence, a typical advertisement for the popular detergent known as **All**. (If you don't know the brand, surely you've heard the phrases  " **all** -purpose detergent" or " **all** -temperature detergent.");1) [[esaulgd](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/esaulgd)] 25-1-2007(227): If you _compare_ colors, you will find that _white_ is produced from the mix of **all** the others.;2) [[AndamanIslander](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/AndamanIslander)] 29-1-2008(141): Sometimes, Dr. Heisig's keyword choices are really quite bizarre. This doesn't mean **all** , it means **everyone**!! Picture two ku klux klansmen _comparing_ whose _skin_ is whiter…finally, they agree that **everyone** there is white.
必;invariably;First note the stroke order of this character, which did not really evolve from the _heart_ , even though we take it that way. If one takes it as a pictograph "dividing" _the heart_ in half, then one has one of those **invariably** true bits of human anatomy: the fact that each _heart_ is divided into two halves.;1) [[dwhitman](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dwhitman)] 27-10-2007(203): You swear you'll be in love forever, but **invariably** there comes a time when your _heart_ is _divided_.;2) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 12-6-2008(97): For this kanji I **invariably** got the stroke order wrong. I nearly lost _heart_ , but decided to _stick_ (pun) to it. Then I noticed the order is 1) katakana ソ (altered slightly), 2) fishhook, 3) two drops. Now I **invariably** get it right.
歌;song;The **song** in this kanji is being sung by a chorus line of _can-can_ girls. Why it should be eliciting nothing but _yawning_ from the audience, I leave to you to decide.;1) [[Ameyama](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Ameyama)] 4-4-2008(138): **Can- Can** -ers **lack** the ability to sing a **song** , so they just dance.;2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 17-12-2006(64): _Can-can_ dancers are supposed to be big-bosomed girls who dance. Yet these so called can-can dancers are flat-chested and singing a **song** , so audience of men is _yawn_ ing in boredom.
打;strike;Finger . . . spike.;1) [[fuaburisu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/fuaburisu)] 30-1-2007(258): You're using a hammer to drive a _nail_ into a plank, but you miss and **strike** your _fingers_ , ouch ! PS: the character does not mean "to go on **strike** ", it will be very helpful in the long run to create images that convey the proper sense of the character!;2) [[Wosret](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Wosret)] 23-2-2009(43): My teacher used to **strike** my **finger** s with a **street sign**.
呼;call;_Mouth_ . . . _water lily_. Note: this is the one time that the  "stem" has a barb at the end. 根;root;Tree . . . silver.;1) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 28-10-2007(227): Since trees eat through their **root** s, one could imagine **root** s as _tree silver_ ware.;2) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 1-3-2007(109): The **root** s of the magical _tree_ are _silver_.
覚;memorize;The idea of **memorizing** things is easily related to the _schoolhouse_ , and since we have been at it for more than a hundred pages in this book, the idea that **memorizing** involves _seeing_ things that are not really there should make it easy to put the two elements together.;1) [[NooNoo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/NooNoo)] 25-4-2008(180): In a _schoolhouse_ in class: 1) you _see_ something on the blackboard, then 2) you **memorize** it.;2) [[cerulean](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/cerulean)] 1-7-2008(82): You'll never **memorize** all the kanji by _seeing_ them in a _school house_. 老;old man;First, do not confuse this character with _venerable old man_ (Frame 849), which is far more rarely used. The character for an **old man** begins with an abbreviation of the character for _somebody_ , the _nose_ having been shortened into a simple crisscross of lines. But there is another, simpler way to remember it all: the _soil_ drawn first indicates that one has come close to the age when  "dust to dust" begins to take on a personal meaning, the diagonal _walking stick_ for getting around, and the _spoon_ for being spoon- fed.;1) [[ayoung24](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ayoung24)] 18-12-2006(200): An **old man** , wondering what it's like in a grave, _sits_ in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with _soil_ , the **old man** saves himself by flailing his _walking stick_ in the air.;2) [[aphasiac](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/aphasiac)] 14-8-2009(71): The _dirty_ **old man** had a _stroke_ so now he must be _spoon_ fed.
京;capital;When we think of a **capital**  city today we think of _tall_  skyscrapers dwarfing the endless swarms of _little_  folk scurrying here and there about their business.;1) [[mhheie](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/mhheie)] 21-9-2006(243): Tokyo, **capital** of Japan: _tall_ buildings, _small_ people (compared to the buildings).;2) [[Cirion](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Cirion)] 20-7-2008(69): The **capital** is where the powerful act formal wearing _top hats_ , open their _mouth_ s, and get _little_ done.
由;wherefore;The " **wherefore** " of this kanji explains the reason or origin of a thing. It does this graphically by depicting a seed in a _rice field_ sending up a single sprout, which is the whole why and **wherefore** of the seed's falling in the earth and dying. (When the _flower_ appears, you will recall from frame 249, we have a full _seedling_.);1) [[Katsuo](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Katsuo)] 13-11-2007(155): " **Wherefore** art thou, _Sprouteo_?" (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet's dinner plate and rolled off).;2) [[DrJones](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/DrJones)] 16-1-2008(152): "Cogito **ergo** sum." **Wherefore** is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it's often mistranslated as "where" when in fact it's an urge to know a cause or reason, and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought _sprouts_ from my _brain_. I think, **therefore** I am.].
品;goods;As in the character for _sparkle_ , the triplication of a single element in this character indicates "everywhere" or "heaps of." When we think of **goods** in modern industrial society, we think of what has been mass- produced - that is to say, produced for the  "masses" of open _mouths_ waiting like fledglings in a nest to  "consume" whatever comes their way.;1) [[Tsuki11](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Tsuki11)] 29-10-2007(93): _Three boxes_ of **goods** are devoured by the hungry _mouths_ of waiting consumers.;2) [[graham6565](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/graham6565)] 16-5-2007(68): Three hungry mouths waiting for the **goods** to come.
治;reign;Water . . . pedestal.;1) [[taijuando](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taijuando)] 6-5-2006(389): From his _water_ _pedestal_ Neptune **reign** s over his Sea Empire.;2) [[Stormchild](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/Stormchild)] 17-7-2006(40): Build a moat around your pedestal to protect your **reign** of power.
調;tune;A complete **tune** is composed not only of a succession of notes but also of one _lap_ of the _words_ that go with it.;1) [[ihatobu](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/ihatobu)] 7-2-2009(220): To **tune** an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the _circumference_ , until you can clearly hear what's being _said_.;2) [[canji](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/canji)] 24-8-2008(127): _words_ \+ _circumference_ The most catchy **tunes** are _words_ the go round and round the _circuference_ of your head and you can't get it out of your mind.
姿;figure;This kanji depicts a _woman's_ **figure** as a sort of _second_ self.;1) [[alantin](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/alantin)] 25-10-2007(212): The next woman always has a better **figure**! Thinking like that, you'll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days!;2) [[elanlan](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/elanlan)] 30-1-2009(110): Whenever I am _next_ to a _woman_ , I can't help but take notice of her **figure**.
読;read;In the age of advertising, most _words_ we **read** are out to _sell_ some product or point of view.;1) [[taikura](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/taikura)] 10-11-2008(160): People will _say_ ( 言 ) almost anything to make a _sale_ ( 売 ), don't believe everything you **read** ( 読 ).;2) [[richcoop](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/richcoop)] 28-6-2009(84): **Read** the WORDS used to SELL things.
病;ill;Sickness . . . third class.;1) [[dingomick](http://kanji.koohii.com/profile/dingomick)] 24-12-2007(239): _Caveman_ got **ill** after flying _third class_. The cabin air and food got to him.
